In the future, she wants to expand her business and be able to supply meals for enterprises.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bUYING RICE AND GRAINS TO PREPARE MEALS TO SELL

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Victoria pertenece al  Banco Comunal Señor de Huanca y lo que mas le gusta es el incentivo al ahorro.
Victoria es casada y tiene 4 hijos que estudian, Victoria viaja a las ciudades de Pisco e Ica en donde vende cereales variados, productos que adquiere en el mercado de Abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho y también de productores que le llevan a su casa, en algunas oportunidades dependiendo de la demanda procesa los cereales, Victoria viaja los días viernes y regresa los días lunes. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de trigo, cebada y maíz.
Victoria hace algunos meses inicio a construir su casa son sus ahorros del Banco Comunal y espera terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Victoria is a member of the Communal Bank “Señor de Huanca” and what she enjoys most is having the incentive to save. She is married and has four children in school. Victoria travels to the cities of Pisco and Ica where she sells different grains. She acquires her products at the suppliers’ market in city of Ayacucho. On a few occasions, producers will deliver goods to her house if there is a demand for processed grain. Victoria travels on Thursdays and returns on Mondays.

Her loan of 2000 PEN will be invested in the purchase of wheat, barley, and corn. A few months ago, Victoria started the construction of her house using her Communal Bank savings and she hopes to have it finished.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wheat, barley, and corn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase two cows

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es:
Ana es casada y tiene 3 hijos que estudian, Ana junto a su esposo tienen una panadería en su casa, su horno es rustico de leña, elaboran biscochos y queques, sus ventas los realizan a las tiendas, reparten con su carro propio, que compro con ahorros, lo cual ayudo a incrementar sus ventas porque puede llegar a lugares mas lejanos. 
Ana es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Huanca y solicita un préstamo de 400 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar.
Ana sueña con comprar otro terreno e implementar su panadería con un horno eléctrico que le facilitaría el trabajo forzado que hasta ahora realiza.
texts.en:
Ana is married and has 3 children, all of whom are students. Ana and her husband operate a bakery in their house. They bake cookies and cakes with a traditional wood oven and they sell their products to stores, distributing them with their own car, which she bought with her savings. This helps their sales, since they are able to reach distant locations. Ana is a member of the Señor de Huanca Communal Bank and she is soliciting a loan of 400 sols, money that will be invested in purchasing sugar. Ana dreams of buying more land and supplying her bakery with an electric oven, which would facilitate the hard work that, up until now, they have done.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING SUGAR TO USE IN BAKING GOODS TO SELL

loans.name: Ambrosia

texts.es:
Ambrosia es soltera, tiene 2 hijos que estudian en la universidad y su mayor sueño es que ellos culminen sus estudios, Ambrosia vive en una casa alquilada y su meta es ahorrar lo suficiente y comprar un terreno para construir su casa. 
Ambrosía es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Huanca y durante este tiempo aprendió a ser puntual y sobre todo a ahorrar, Ambrosia vende emoliente (bebida caliente de hierbas y semillas de lino con propiedades curativas), actividad que realiza por las mañanas y noches, cuenta con una carreta con la cual se ubica en un jirón transitado. Además en sus tiempos libres Ambrosia trabaja en una empresa embolsando productos. Ambrosia necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar y hierbas.
texts.en:
Ambrosia is single and has two children studying at university and her biggest dream is for them to finish their studies. Ambrosia lives in a rented house and her goal is to save enough to buy land and build her house. Ambrosia is a member of the communal bank "Señor de Huanca." As a member of the bank she has learned to be punctual and above all to save. Ambrosia sells "emolliente" (a hot herb drink with flax seeds and healing properties), which she does in the mornings and nights from a cart she stations on a well traveled street. In addition, in her free time Ambrosia works for a company bagging products. Ambrosia needs a loan of 1000 soles to invest in the purchase of sugar and herbs.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar and herbs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy materials to build a restraining wall

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.es:
Alejandrina pertenece al Banco Comunal Señor de Huanca.
Alejandrina es casada y tiene 9 hijos de los cuales 6 viven con ella, Alejandrina vende anticuchos (comida preparada con corazón a la parrilla), diariamente se ubica en un parque que se encuentra cerca de un instituto, actividad que realiza por las noches. Además Alejandrina trabaja en una granja de pollos por las madrugadas en donde pela pollos. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra de carne.
Alejandrina sueña con construir su casa de material noble pues es de material rustico y brindar educación a todos sus hijos.
texts.en:
Alejandrina belongs to the Señor de Huanta Communal Bank. Alejandrina is married and has nine children. Six of her children live with her. Alejandrina sells “anticuchos” (a Quechuan skewered meat prepared in a base of the animal's heart). Everyday she is located in a park that is close to an institute, and she sells at night. Also, Alejandrina works on a chicken farm in the mornings; she plucks chicken. Her loan will be used to buy meat. Alejandrina dreams of building her house from sturdy material; it is now made of rudimentary materials. She also dreams of giving all of her children an education.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy meat

loans.name: Leoncia

texts.es:
Leoncia vive en casa alquilada y su mayor sueño es comprar un terreno para la construcción de su casa, Leoncia es separada y tiene 7 hijos de los cuales 3 estudian, Leoncia vende comida de manera ambulatoria en un paradero de autobuses, actividad que realiza todos los días, también Leoncia vende chicha en el mismo lugar de 3 de la tarde hasta las 9 de la noche. Además Leoncia se dedica al engorde de ganado porcino en su casa.
Leoncia es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Huanca y solicita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cerdos pequeños.
texts.en:
Leoncia lives in a rented house. Her biggest dream is to buy a piece of land in order to build her house. Leoncia is separated, and she has seven children. Three of the children go to school. Leoncia sells food as a street vendor at a bus stop. She does this everyday. Also, Leoncia sells “chicha” (beverage made from fermented corn) at the same place from three in the afternoon until nine at night. Additionally, Leoncia fattens pigs at her house. Leoncia is a member of the Señor de Huanca Communal Bank. She is requesting a loan for 1,000 soles to buy small pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy small pigs

loans.name: Paulino

texts.es:
Paulino es un padre de familia de 54 años de edad que vive junto a su esposa y a sus tres hijos en el sector Amaru Inca - Valle de Los Incas, una zona agrícola del distrito de Tambogrande, un distrito que tiene como actividad principal el cultivo de plantas frutales, las cuales son debidamente tratadas y exportadas al exterior, la zona pertenece a la provincia de Piura, en la región del mismo nombre, ubicada a tres horas y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

Se dedica desde joven a labores asociadas a la agricultura, actualmente tiene dos hectáreas de cultivo en las cuales ha sembrado árboles de mango y de limón, el, como todos los agricultores de la zona, vende las frutas que producen sus árboles a las plantas de tratamiento, las cuales procesan las frutas para exportarlas a diversos países del exterior.

El depende de esta actividad para poder solventar los gastos económicos familiares, por ello trabaja arduamente para obtener una buena producción en cada cosecha. Actualmente el desea brindar mantenimiento a su cultivo de limón aplicandole fertilizantes, por ello ha solicitado por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Paulino es un hombre trabajador y honesto, sumayor anhelo es poder brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida, las personas que lo conocen en la zona donde vive le consideran alguien de confianza.
texts.en:
Paulino is a 54-year-old father who lives with his wife and three children in the area Amaru Inca - Valley of the Incas. This is an agricultural area in the Tambogrande district, a district where people make a living primarily by growing fruit plants, which are adequately treated and exported abroad. The area is part of the province of Piura, in the region of the same name, located three hours from the city of Chiclayo, the capital of the Lambayeque region. Paulino has worked in farming since he was young and currently has two hectares in which he has planted mango and lemon trees. He, like all farmers in the area, sells his fruit to the treatment factories, which process the fruits for export to various countries abroad. He depends on this work to take care of his family's financial needs, therefore he works very hard to get a good yield out of each harvest. Currently, he would like to maintain his crops and apply fertilizer to his lemon trees. Therefore, he is taking out a loan for the first time from "Edpyme Alternativa" of 1,000 soles to help him achieve his goal. Paulino is a hard worker and is honest and his greatest desire is to give his family a better quality of life. People who know the area where he lives consider him someone you trust.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertalizer to put on his lemon crop.

loans.name: Alfonsa

texts.es:
Alfonsa es conviviente y tiene 4 hijos de los cuales 2 estudian, Alfonsa tiene un bar en su casa en donde vende bebidas, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda eventual de su esposo. Además Alfonsa junto a su esposo son artesanos textiles, actividad que realiza con ayuda de tejedores, Alfonsa se dedica al bordado de los productos, sus productos los vende a intermediarios que llevan a la ciudad de Cusco y Puno. También tienen un grupo musical. Solicita un crédito de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de instrumentos musicales. 
Alfonsa sueña con mejorar su casa con acabados, techar el segundo piso y ayudar a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Alfonsa lives with a partner and has 4 children, 2 of whom are in school. Alfonsa has a bar in her house where she sells drinks. She works in this business every day, with the occasional help of her husband. In addition, Alfonsa and her husband make artisan textiles with the help of weavers. Alfonsa embroiders the products, and they are sold to traders that come from the city of Cusco and Puno. In addition, they have a musical group. She requests a loan of 1,500 Peruvian soles that she will invest in the purchase of musical instruments. Alfonsa dreams of finishing construction on her home by putting a roof on the second floor, and of being able to help her children.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy musical instruments

loans.name: Esther

texts.es:
Esther pertenece al Banco Comunal Despertar hace 1 años y aprendió a administrar mejor su negocio y a ahorrar.
Esther vive en la casa de sus suegros y su mayor sueño es construir su casa, Esther es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos pequeños, tiene un puesto alquilado en el mercado 12 de abril en donde vende ropa variada, Esther comienza su día de trabajo a las 8 de la mañana hasta las 6 de la tarde, negocio que inicio hace 5 años. Esther solicita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de polos, pantalones de niños.
El esposo se Esther estudia en la Universidad y su mayor sueño es que termine sus estudios, además de construir su casa y educar a sus hijos.
texts.en:
For the past year, Esther has pertained to the Communal Bank, Despertar, and has learnt to manage her business better and to save money. She lives in the home of her in-laws and her greatest dream is to construct a home of her own. Esther has got two small children and rents a stall at the 12 de abril market, where she sells various types of clothing. Esther begins her day at 8am in the morning and works until 6pm in the afternoon in her business which she began 5 years ago. She is applying for a loan of 3000 soles which she plans on investing in the purchase of polo shirts and children's pants. Esther's husband studies at the University and his greatest dream is to finish his studies, in addition to constructing a house and educating his children.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase polo shirts and children's pants.

loans.name: Flor De Maria

texts.es:
Flor pertenece al Banco Comunal Despertar hace 1 año y lo que mas le agrada es el incentivo al ahorro.
Flor es casada y tiene 2 hijos que estudian, Flor vende salchipollos de manera ambulante en el mercado de las Américas, actividad que realiza todos los días desde las 3 de la tarde hasta las 10 de la noche, negocio que inicio hace 5 años, por las mañanas se encarga del cuidado de sus hijos. Solicita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de aceite, cremas, gas y papa.
Su sueño es educar a sus hijos y tener casa propia porque vive en casa alquilada.
texts.en:
For the past year, Flor has been a member of the Communal Bank, Despertar, and what appeals to her most are the savings incentives. Flor is married and has got 2 children that attend school. Flor sells salchipollos (a dish that consists of shredded chicken or hotdog served over french fries) at the Las Américas market, a job that she does every day from 3 in the afternoon until 10 at night. She began this business five years ago. In the morning, she takes care of her children. She is applying for a loan of 1500 soles which she plans to invest in the purchase of oil, sauces, gas, and potatoes. Her dream is to educate her children and have her own house, since she is currently renting hers.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase oil, sauces, potatoes and gas.

loans.name: Nancy Lucila

texts.es:
Nancy es conviviente y tiene 1 hijo de años, Nancy y su esposo venden ropa variada, tiene 2 puestos en el mercado 12 de abril, uno es propio y el otro es alquilado, actividad que realiza desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche todos los días, además en algunas oportunidades viaja a las ferias donde también vende ropa. 
Nancy es socia del Banco Comunal Despertar y solicita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que sera invertido en la compra de pantalones, polos.
Nancy sueña con tener una tienda estable y una casa propia.
texts.en:
Nancy is married and has got one child. Her and her husband sell various types of clothing. They have two stalls at the 12 de abril Market, one of which they own and the other is rented. They begin at 7 in the morning and work until 8 at night every day. In addition, on certain occasions, they travel to fairs where they also sell their clothing. Nancy is a member of the Communal Bank Despertar and is applying for a credit of 2000 soles, which she plans on investing in the purchase of pants and polo shirts. Nancy's dream is to have a stable store and her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase pants and polo shirts.

loans.name: Mujeres Con Decision  ( Cuenca ) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Mujeres con Decisión esta formado por un grupo de 11 socias quienes buscan con su trabajo brindar a sus familias un mejor futuro y entregarles una mejor estabilidad económica, viven en varios lugares de la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es reconocida por sus hermosas iglesias, sus ríos, sus gastronomía que es muy variada y su gente que es muy cordial y amable.

La Señora María C. vive en el centro de la ciudad de Cuenca, es su primer crédito que realiza en la fundación  y ha sido invitada por una gran amiga que pertenece al banco comunal. Se dedica a realizar bordados hace 10 años y ha sido su hermana quien le ha  enseñado este hermoso oficio, labora desde las 10 a.m., hasta las 6 de la tarde de lunes a viernes.

Nuestra socia tiene 24 años de edad, vive en unión libre y tiene 2 hijos quienes se encuentran de 4 y 3 años de edad, su esposo trabaja como mesero, no tiene casa propia por lo que vive arrendando. Su crédito lo va  a utilizar en la compra de víveres para su hogar. Su sueño es de algún día tener su casa propia.

La Señora Rosa Z. vive por la comunidad de San Pedro del Cebollar, tiene 56 años de edad, es casada y tiene 8 hijos de los cuales 7 ya son casados y viven de manera independiente,  tiene una hija de quince años que vive en su casa y esta estudiando en una academia de corte y confección, su esposo se dedica al reciclaje, gracias al trabajo y esfuerzo conyugal han logrado tener su casa propia.

Nuestra socia se dedica a vender chancho horneado  los fines de semana y vende  recorriendo el mercado 10 de Agosto, este trabajo realiza desde  soltera, el resto de la semana se dedica a la cría de cuyes, chanchos, sus animalitos los vende en su casa.  Nuestra socia se encuentra en la banca comunal hace 3 años y en todo ese tiempo ha logrado tener una  buena amistad con todas las socias,  su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de chanchos y  alimento, su meta es  tener un negocio más grande.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Mujeres con Decisión" is made up of a group of 11 members who seek with their work to provide their families with a better future and better economic stability. They live in various parts of the city of Cuenca. Cuenca is a city that is known for its beautiful churches, its rivers, its varied cuisine, and its people who are very cordial and friendly. Señora María C. lives in the center of the city of Cusco. This is the first loan that she has taken with the fundación. She was invited to join the group by a close friend who is a member. She has been doing embroidery for 10 years; it was her sister who taught her how to do this beautiful work. She works from 10am until 6pm Monday through Friday. María is 24 years old and is in a common-law marriage; she has 2 children who are 3 and 4 years old. Her husband works as a waiter. They do not have their own home, and so are renting. She will use this loan to buy groceries for her home. She dreams of some day having her own home. Señora Rosa Z. lives in the community of San Pedro del Cebollar. She is 56 years old, married, and has 8 children, 7 of whom are married and live independently. She has a 15 year-old daughter who lives in the house and who is studying dressmaking. Her husband works in recycling. Thanks to hard work and a lot of effort, the couple has managed to have their own home. Rosa sells baked pork on the weekends, walking through the "10 de Agosto" market, an activity she has been doing since she was single. During the rest of the week she raises guinea pigs and pigs, and she sells her small animals from her house. Rosa joined this communal bank 3 years ago, and over that time she has developed a good friendship with all of the members. She will invest this new loan in the purchase of pigs and feed. Her goal is to have a bigger business.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy pigs and pig feed / to buy groceries

loans.name: Sugey Katherine

texts.es:
Sugey es una madre de familia de 22 años de edad, tiene un hijo menor de edad y vive en casa de su madre, ubicada en el caserío La Zaranda del distrito de Pítipo, un sector agrícola de la provincia de Ferreñafe, se encuentra ubicado a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace tres años a trabajar en el negocio de crianza y venta de animales menores, ella cría sus animales en un potrero (bosque de algarrobos) situado cerca al domicilio en donde vive. Cuando sus animales ya ha alcanzado un buen nivel de desarrollo los ofrece en venta a los negociantes que siempre visitan la zona en donde vive.

Como ya lleva tiempo trabajando en esta actividad, ella ha podido ahorrar y con ese dinero empezó hace poco un negocio de venta de medicamentos, este negocio tiene mucha utilidad en la zona donde vive ya que se encuentran alejados del pueblo mas cercano y no cuentan conuna farmacia queles venda medicinas en caso de urgencias. Con los ingresos que ella percibe de estas actividades mantiene a su hijo y ayuda a su madre con los gastos familiares.

Sugey desea seguir trabajando en el negocio de compra y venta de animales, por ello ha solicitado un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de animales menores para criarlos y venderlos.

Ella es una joven madre que da lo mejor de si para lograr el bienestar de su hijo. En la zona donde vive sus vecinos y conocidos le consideran una joven trabajadora y honesta.
texts.en:
Sugey is a 22 year old mother, with a small child, and lives in her mother's house located in the housing complex La Zaranda in the Pítipo district, a farming area of the Ferreñafe province. It is located 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. She has been making a living for the last three years raising and selling small animals. She raises her animals in a pasture (carob tree forest) near where she lives. When her animals reach a good level of development, she puts them up for sale for the merchants that always visit the area where she resides. Since she has been working in this trade for some time, she has been able to save and has recently started a business of selling medicine. This business is very useful in this area because they are far removed from the nearby town and do not have a pharmacy that will provide medicine in emergencies. With the income from both of these activities she can support her son and help her mother with the household expenses. Sugey wants to continue working on the business of buying and selling of the animals, that is the reason for requesting the loan of 2000 new soles which she plans to invest in the purchase of small animals to raise and then sell. She is a young mother that gives the best of herself for the benefit of her son. In the area where she lives, her neighbors consider her a hard working and honest young woman.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase small animals to expand the business of raising and selling them.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane J., 34, resides in Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Juan J., a carpenter, and mother of seven children.

Mary Jane operates a balut-selling business. Balut, which is a fertilized duck egg, is sold as a night snack, peddled during twilight hours very much like fish and chips. Balut is a delicacy enjoyed by many Filipinos because of its health benefits.  Balut is considered to be an aphrodisiac and a power food, as many people believe it gives a sudden boost of energy.  Mary Jane peddles balut on street corners together with boiled regular duck eggs, boiled peanuts and pork skin crackling. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php600 in gross sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, Mary Jane is requesting a Php12,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantities of her products to be incorporated into her everyday inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Mary Jane dreams to be able to give her all of her children a good, high-quality education through her hard work. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: To buy more product to sell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira G., 58, resides in Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Thomas G., a Jeepney driver, and is the mother of five children.

Elvira operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the working community and most families only eat home-cooked meals in the evenings when all family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a family custom but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and food costs less than raw food. 

Elvira's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 1,000 in gross sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more meat, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Elvira dreams of giving all of her children a good, high-quality education through her hard work. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita F., 50, resides in Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Alexander F., a machine operator, and is the mother of a teen currently enrolled in high school. Lolita is working hard to send her child all the way through college. She was once a college undergraduate and she believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Lolita operates a siomai buying-and-selling business.  Siomai is a small Chinese dumpling filled with either pork, beef or shark's fin.  Lolita buys siomai from wholesalers and sell them piecemeal, making a little profit. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, Lolita is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy additional siomai and other products to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Lolita dreams of being able to give her child a good, high-quality education through her hard work. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina L., 37, resides in Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Primo L., a vendor, and is the mother of four children, one of whom is in college while the rest are staying at home. By the grace of God, Lina has managed to support her older child's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining children all the way through college. Lina herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Lina operates a variety store where she also does a little direct selling. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Lina gets her supplies at a wholesale price and sells at a smal profit.  Her store is located next to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 21,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Lina dreams of giving all her children a good, high-quality education through her hard work. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory

loans.name: Esnarda

texts.en:
This is Esnarda M., a 60-year-old retiree and resident of Pasay City, Philippines.
 
Esnarda operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Philippine pesos' (Php) worth of cooking oil or an egg. Esnarda earns by getting supplies at a wholesale price and selling at a piece rate. Esnarda’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php42,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands this business.
  
Esnarda dreams to be a member of CCT as long as she lives. She envisions her business to be stable, and she knows that there are people who will help her achieve her dreams.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana owns a small business, selling women's underwear at the central market in Ivano-Frankovsk, Ukraine. She started this business 4 years ago, when she graduated from High school. She followed her mother's example, her mother had a similar business and extensive sales experience.

During the 4 years Tatyana has learnt the advantages and hardships of being in a small business. She enjoys being independent and is ready to work hard to reach her current business goal, which is to start a second location. Tatyana is asking for a loan of 12,000 UAH to purchase more inventory. 

Tatyana is single and this business is her only source of income.

loans.use: to purchase inventory

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
This is Elizabeth M., 54, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. Currently separated from her husband and solely supporting her child, Elizabeth is working hard to be able to provide a high quality education for her child. That is a dream for most Filipino parents like Elizabeth.  She is a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Elizabeth operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Juanita earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them at piece rate. Elizabeth’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of Php21, 000. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Elizabeth dreams of having her own house someday.

loans.use: Expand her product inventory

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
This is Sarah C., a widow at 47, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is currently struggling to support her five children. One of her children is already working and helping her with the finances, one is in college, one in high school, one in elementary while the youngest is still toddling around at home with her. By the grace of God, Sarah has managed to support schooling for her older children up to college level. Now, she is working hard to send her remaining children all the way through college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Sarah, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Sarah operates a fruit and vegetable stand. She buys seasonal fruits that are native to the Philippines like pineapples, which are grown mostly in the south region of Luzon. She also sells green and ripe mangoes, melons, watermelons, and other Filipino fruit staples. Also in her product inventory are garlic and onions, tomatoes and other staples for simple cooking recipes. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a a loan for Php15, 000. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of fruit and vegetables to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Sarah dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education, through hard work at her business.

loans.use: Expand her product inventory

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
This is Consuelo H., 50, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Melchor H., a food vendor, and is the mother of three children, one of whom is still in college. She is working hard to be able to support her child’s schooling all the way through college until he gets his degree. This is very important for Consuelo as she knows the importance of having a diploma to be able to work in a decent and well-paying job.

Consuelo operates a food stall. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 1,000 in gross sales every day.

In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings when all the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands cost less than raw food.

To help her continue operations of her business, Consuelo is requesting a Php 11,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Consuelo hopes that her little business will someday be the restaurant she always dreamt it would be.

loans.use: To buy quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
This is Jennifer L., 33, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Jerry L., a pedicab (a bicycle with sidecar that can carry a maximum of five people) driver, and is the mother of four children, one of whom is already in college while the other three are in high school.

By the grace of God, Jennifer has managed to support her older child's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Jennifer. She, herself, has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Jennifer operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to to buy one sachet of shampoo, Php 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg.

Jennifer earns by getting supplies at a wholesale price and selling retail. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Jennifer is requesting a Php 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
 
Jennifer dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business.

loans.use: To buy quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Remelita

texts.en:
This is Remelita R., a resident of Pasay City, Philippines, is a 32-year-old mother of a highschooler and is married to Marco Antonio R., a driver. By the grace of God, Remelita has managed to thus far support her child’s schooling, at this time working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college, a dream for most Filipino parents. Remelita herself has been a college undergraduate and strongly believes that a college diploma is the best legacy parents can leave to their children.

Remelita maintains a direct-selling business, selling clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through popular direct-selling brands such as Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, etc. Each customer's order, paid for in cash by the dealer, is then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealers' prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and those differences are the basis of the dealers' income. Remelita's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community, and she earns a minimum of Php1,200 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php14,000 loan which she will use to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. Remelita dreams of being able to give her child a high-quality education through all of her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have her own house and lot someday.

loans.use: To buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
This is Conchita M., 57, resident of Tanza, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Mauro M., a church pastor, and is the mother of five children, all of whom are already settled down with their own families. She has managed to support her children’s education, a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Conchita as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Conchita operates a slipper-making business. Because of the hot climate and humidity here in the Philippines, slippers, flip-flops and sandals are the most common kind of footwear, especially for people working in the fields, streets and their homes. Conchita manufactures all types of slippers, made of different materials from cloth to leather to rubber. Her regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community.  She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy the raw materials necessary to continue production of her slippers. She will purchase rubber, leather, cloth, thread, rugby and other kinds of supplies. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands the business.  

Conchita dreams of being able to give all her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work with the business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: to buy the raw materials necessary to continue production of her slippers

loans.name: Rosally

texts.en:
This is Rosally D. C., 23, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Roberto D. C. and is the mother of a toddler.
 
Rosally operates a soft drink business. She bulk buys cases of assorted soft drinks then supplies variety stores in the immediate area. Because not many variety stores are big enough to order their own supply, this arrangement works out pretty well. Rosally’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a 34,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy larger quantities of products to incorporate into her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands the business.  

Rosally dreams of having her own house, lot and car one day from all her hard work with the business.

loans.use: to buy larger quantities of products

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine M., 29, is single and a resident of Pasay City, Philippines.
 
Josephine operates a computer shop. Most Filipino households don’t have computers, so students who need to do research, print typed papers and use computer services rent out units on an hourly basis. It is also a very popular way to socialize through online gaming, chatting and using social networking sites. Josephine mainly caters to students and young people, but her regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting an 18,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy needed upgrading software, hardware and accessories. She also will invest some of the loan for repairs needed in the shop. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands the business. 
 
Josephine is hoping that she will one day have her own house and lot, courtesy of the profits from her computer shop.

loans.use: to buy upgrading software, hardware and accessories and for repairs needed in the shop

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
This is Leticia D. C., a widow at 55, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She has a child who is struggling through his high school years.  By the grace of God, Leticia has managed to support her child’s schooling by herself.  At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college. A dream for most poor Filipino parents like Leticia as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Leticia operates a bakery. Breads and spreads are staples in the usual Filipino cuisine, and are used mostly for breakfast and snacks. The most popular type of bread is the Pandesal, a Filipino version of the Spanish Pan de Sal or salted bread. It is baked during the wee hours of the morning and sold steaming hot to early commuters, students and workers. It is also packed hot into a Styrofoam box and sold in the streets, mostly recognized by the honking of the bicycle boy who carries and sells them. Leticia’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 50,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy raw supplies like flour, sugar, and butter, which she needs to continue production and expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Leticia hopes that her business will be successful one day, enough for her to buy her own house, lot, and car for her retirement.

loans.use: buying raw ingredients for bread production

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en:
Jeniffer is a member of the Mwendi Utheri group in Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner. She operates a food kiosk to earn a living. She started this business three years ago.  

Jeniffer, who is a single mother of four, works hard to provide for the family. She hopes to expand her business so as to get more income for raising up her children. She has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase an energy-saving cooker and an oven. 

She sees herself opening a hotel in the future.

loans.use: To purchase an energy-saving cooker and an oven

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Geofrey

texts.en:
Geofrey is a 37-year-old married man. He is blessed with three children: twins aged 12 and a 5-year-old.  To earn a living, he sells maize and potatoes in an open-air market. He has been running the business for three years and has seen the business grow since he joined Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner. 

He appreciates Faulu Kenya for previously giving him a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES), which he used to boost the business. Currently, he has five employees who help him in the day-to-day running of the business. He is requesting a loan of 80,000 KES to purchase 20 sacks of maize.  

Geofrey hopes to supply maize in schools in his local community. This way, he will get more income for investing in another business.

loans.use: To buy 20 bags of maize

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a 30-year-old farmer. He is married with two children who go to school. He does dairy farming and sells milk to Fresha Co-operative, a well-known milk-processing company in Kenya. He has been in the business for four years and hopes to expand the business.  

Paul joined the Nuru investment group in Faulu Kenya so as to access a loan easily. Through the group, he has managed to service one loan worth 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). He has been guaranteed another loan of 40,000 KES by the group. He will use this loan to buy a dairy cow so as to increase production.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a 25-year-old married man. To earn a living, he sells charcoal. He has been engaged in the business for two years and has one employee. He has been a member of a group in Faulu Kenya (a Kiva partner) whose members are responsible for any member who takes out a loan. In this group, he saves his money on weekly basis.  

He has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to add stock of charcoal. Joseph is a hardworking man who hopes to purchase a lorry (truck) for transporting charcoal in the future.

loans.use: To add stock of charcoal

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is a 33-year-old married lady with three children. She sells food and operates a grocery shop. She has been in the business for five years with one employee. She has been an active member of a group in Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner. 

She previously took out a loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) through the group. She has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to increase stock of beans, maize, vegetables and fruits. She hopes to provide a quality education for her children.

loans.use: To increase stock of beans, maize, vegetables and fruits

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a hardworking lady who operates a retail shop. She sells sodas, cakes, bread, maize flour, wheat flour, soap and cooking fat. She has been running the business for three years and has employed one person.  

As a member of Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to keep business records and save her money. She wants to invest in her business so as to get enough capital for expanding her shop into a wholesale business. She needs a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to add stock of sodas, cakes, bread, maize flour, wheat flour, soap and cooking fat.

loans.use: To add stock of sodas, cakes, bread, maize flour, wheat flour, soap and cooking fat

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a 29-year-old single mother of one.  She has raised her 2-year-old child with income from her business. She has been selling clothes for three years.  

She joined a group under Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner, so as to access loans and to save her money. So far, she has serviced two loans from Faulu Kenya. This has helped her improve her business. She is requesting another loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to add stock of clothes.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a member of the Winners Kitengela group in Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner. He does transport business using his car. He has three years of experience in this business and has one employee. Besides being a businessman, he is a church pastor. 

Richard, who is married with five children, works hard to provide for the family. Currently, his greatest challenge is repairing his car, which is in bad condition. Hence, he is requesting 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy spare parts. He hopes to open his own transport company in the future so as to get huge business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for repairing his car

loans.name: Sofiah

texts.en:
Sofiah is a 27-year-old married lady with three children, aged 12, 8 and 2. She has been operating a retail shop for three years, selling foodstuffs and other household items. She is glad to be associated with Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner, because she is able to access loans and save money on a weekly basis.  

She previously took out a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES), which she used to improve her business. She was able to pay the loan without any challenge; hence, she has been allowed to take out another loan of 40,000 KES. She will use the loan to purchase sugar, cooking fat, rice and crates of soda. She hopes to expand her shop into a wholesale business in five years.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, cooking fat, rice and crates of soda

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is a member of the Uwo group in Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner. He is 39 years old and married. He has been doing welding for 10 years and makes window frames, grills and metallic gates. He also does farming together with his wife to earn extra income.  

He previously serviced two loans through the Uwo group. This made his business expand and he has employed two people. He has requested a loan of 75,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy scrap metals for making his products. He hopes to expand his business so as to meet his customers’ demand. He dreams of buying a pick-up for transporting his products to his clients.

loans.use: To buy scrap metals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase two packs of better quality clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of fish, shrimp, turtle eggs, crab, lobster, oysters, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase potatoes, onions, oranges, cucumber, plantains, bananas, mangoes, chayote squash, spices, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for an operation and medicines

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy large bags, blouses, and T-shirts with a collar

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing, cologne, lotions etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy products, e.g., basic foodstuffs, soap, eggs, etc., to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Repairs for cattle business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy materials to finish house addition (roofing, etc.)

loans.name: Lino

texts.es:
Lino tiene 47 años de edad, es casado, y vive junto a su familia en un sector urbano – marginal de la ciudad de Chiclayo llamado Villa el Salvador.

Se dedica desde hace mas de diez años a brindar servicio de transporte público dentro de la ciudad de Chiclayo y alrededores en un auto Tico propio que utiliza como taxi. Esta actividad es la unica fuente de ingreso con la que cuenta y gracias a ella puede solventar los gastos familiares y sacar adelante a su familia.

Lino se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1900 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en el mantenimiento y reparación de su vehículo, ya que el contínuo uso otorgado a su unidad móvil ha hecho que esta empiece a sufrir algunas fallas que dificultan su correcto funcionamiento

Lino es un hombre trabajador que dedica la mayor parte del día a brindar su servicio, su mayor anhelo es salir adelante y poner un negocio más estable con el cual percibir mayores ingresos que le permitan brindar una mejor calidad de vida a las personas que quiere. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con Nuestra Institución y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus pagos.
texts.en:
Lino is 47 years old, and he is married. He lives with his family in the Villa el Salvador sector of a marginally urban area of the city of Chiclayo. He has been providing public transportation within the city of Chiclayo and its surroundings for over ten years. He uses his own car, a Tico, as a taxi. This activity is his only source of income. Thanks to this income he is able to pay the family expenses and get his family ahead. Lino is asking Edpyme Alternativa for a loan for 1,900 soles. He plans to use it for maintenance and repairs on his vehicle. The continual use of his vehicle has caused it to start having problems, which hinder proper function. Lino is a hard-working man who devotes most of the day to providing service. His greatest desire is to get ahead and to make his business more stable. Then he will get greater income, which will allow him to give his loved ones a better quality of life. He has worked with our institution previously, and he has demonstrated punctuality and responsibility with his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Maintenance and repair expenses for his vehicle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more products for her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy construction materials, concrete blocks, sand, and labor

loans.name: Dorina Isabel

texts.es:
Dorina Isabel F. M. tiene 27 años de edad, es casada y tiene dos hijos de 11 y 8 años, junto a su familia reside en la colonia Colman en la ciudad de Juticalpa. Hace un tiempo atras comenzo vendiendo ropa usada, ahora ella tiene un negocio de venta de enchape de oro y lo hace de forma ambulante. Sale a vender junto a su tia por las tardes, ya que por la mañana sus hijos van a la escuela y ella tiene que esperar a que lleguen a casa para poder salir. 

El prestamo lo utilizara para construir una habitacion mas en su casa y para eso necesita comprar 700 bloques, 30 varillas, 30 bolsas de cemento, arena, aluzinc, alambre de amarrel. 

Con la construccion de la habitacion su familia estara mas comoda ya que su casa sera mas amplia. Su sueño es que sus hijos crezcan en un ambiente sano y que tengan una educacion para que sean personas autosostenibles.

Dorina ha sido cliente de FAMA por varios ciclos y eso le ha ayudado a darle una mejor vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Dorina Isabel F. M. is 27, married and has two children, 11 and 8. She lives with her family in the Colman neighborhood of the city of Juticalpa. A while ago she began selling used clothing. Now she has a business selling gold plated jewelry as a street vendor. She goes out in the afternoons with her aunt, since her children go to school in the mornings and she has to wait for them to get home before she can leave her house. She will use the loan to build a room on her house and for this she needs 700 cement blocks, 30 rods, 30 bags of cement, sand, aluminum-zinc and wrapping wire. Her family will be more comfortable after the room is built since the house will be bigger. Her dream is for her children to grow up with healthy surroundings and that they have a good education so that they can be self-supporting in the future. Dorina has been a client of FAMA for several cycles and this has helped her give the family a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials for a room

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase products (bananas, cooking oil, and beans)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Cover personal expenses such as purchase of medicine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase brick, cement, wood, sand, and work force.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase building materials (zinc, iron, cement, sand, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase home articles.

loans.name: Mayra Mariby

texts.es:
Mayra Mariby L. V. tiene 30 anos de edad, es soltera y tiene un hijo de 9 anos.  Reside en Colonia Los Angeles en Juticalpa, Olancho, Honduras.  Mayra comenzo vendiendo ropa usada, actualmente se dedica a la venta de comida y sigue con la ropa para obtener mejores ganancias.  Trabaja en el domicilio y la ropa la vende en el mayoreo.  Tambien hace turnos en el hospital donde trabaja como servicio social como esta estudiando enfermeria.  

Mayra usara el prestamo para la legalizacion de un terreno el la Colonia Los Angeles.  Su Papa se le regalo un solar y quiere quiere hacer su casa para que su hija viva mejor.  Una vez que la terreno esta legalizado podra solicitar prestamo mas grande para surtir y ampliar su negocio.  

Su sueno es tener legalizado su propiedad y que el negocio valla creciendo para obtener mejores ganancias y atender mejor a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mayra Mariby L. V. is 30 years old, single, and has a 9 year old child. She resides in the Los Angeles subdivision of Juticalpa, Olancho, Honduras. Mayra started selling used clothing, but she now sells food and continues with her clothing business for extra income. She works from home and sells clothes at the wholesale market. Mayra also works shifts at the hospital as a community service volunteer since she is studying nursing.

She will use this loan to register her property. Her father gave her a plot of land and she wants to build a house so that her daughter can live better. As soon as her property is registered, Mayra will request larger loan so that she can restock and expand her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay to have her property legally registered

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase construction materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase water, sodas, sugar, and other products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase materials needed to repair the roof and the bathroom

loans.name: Elvin Porfirio

texts.es:
Elvin Porfirio F. M. tiene 29 años de edad, es casado y tiene 1 hijo de 6 meses. Reside en el pueblo La Union a dos horas de la Ciudad de Juticalpa. Desde hace tres años tiene un pequeño negocio de venta de lubricantes, accesorios y piezas de repuesto para carros. Su horario de atencion al cliente es desde las 7:00 am hasta las 9:00 pm, el y su esposa se encargan de atenderlo. 

Con el prestamo Elvin surtira su negocio de una mas amplia y variada gama de accesorios y piezas para los carros, asi cuando los vecinos del pueblo necesiten comprar un accesorio o una pieza ya no sera necesario que estos se trasladen hasta la ciudad. 

Su sueño es poder darle una mejor condicion de vida a su esposa e hijo y que el local donde opera sea propio.
texts.en:
Elvin Porfirio F. M. is 29 years old, married, and has a six month old son. He lives in the town of La Union, which is two hours away from the city of Juticalpa. For the past three years he has managed a small business selling lubricants, accessories, and automobile parts. His business is open to customers from 7am until 9pm. He and his wife are responsible for managing the store.

Elvin will use this loan to expand his business by acquiring a wider variety of accessories and auto parts. Whenever his neighbors need these type of products, they no longer have to travel into the city.

Elvin dreams of providing better living conditions for his wife and son. In addition, he hopes to have his own storefront for his business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase auto parts, accessories, and lubricants

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Pay for personal & educational expenses

loans.name: Osman Antonio

texts.es:
Osman de 38 años de edad es soltero, tiene 2 hijos: Alexander de 16 años y Ercka de 14 ambos estudiando la secundaria. Osman trabaja para la Alcaldia Muncipal de Juigalpa desde hace 21 años, desempeñandose como  conductor. 

Esta solicitando  su 1er credito con el objetivo de construir un cuarto y asi poder brindar mayor comodidad a su familia, ya que actualmente comparten el cuarto con sus padres.   

El mayor sueño que Osman tiene es que sus hijos estudian y sean personas de bien, ademas poder tener una vivienda bonita y con las condiciones que su familia necesita.
texts.en:
Osman, 38, is single and has two children: Alexander, 16, and Ercka, 14, both of whom attend high school. Osman has been working at the Juigalpa City Hall for the last 21 years as a driver. Osman will use his first loan to build an addition to the home in which he lives. He'd like to build this addition so that he and his family, who now share a room with his parents, are more comfortable. Osman's dream is that his children will study and be good people, and that they will have a nice home, and better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Violeta Rubiani, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building an addition to his home

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Personal & family expenses

loans.name: Miriam Rosa

texts.es:
Miriam Rosa de 40 años de edad es soltera, tiene 3 hijos: la mayor que esta estudiando en Cuba gracias a una beca que se le dio, Silvio Lenin de 18 años el cual trabaja y apoya a su mamá y Jairy de 11 añitos estudiando el 6to grado de trimaria. 

Miriam trabaja para el INACH desde hace 20 años, desempeñandose como docente de secundaria. Esta solicitando  su 7mo credito con el objetivo de comprar las verjas de las puertas que estan dañadas para brindar mayor seguridad a su vivienda ya que la mayor parte del tiempo la pasa dando clases y si el dienero lo permite repellar un cuarto.  

El mayor sueño que tiene es que sus hijos sean profesionales que le sirvan al pais y poder mejorar su casa poco a poco para poder darle a sus hijos las condiciones basicas que se merecen.
texts.en:
Miriam Rosa is 40 years old, single, and has three sons: the oldest is studying in Cuba thanks to a scholarship he received; Silvio Lenin is 18 years old and works and helps support his mother; and Jairy is just 11 years old and is studying in the 6th grade. Miriam has worked for INACH for 20 years, teaching secondary school. She is requesting her seventh loan, with the objective of replacing the damaged gates on her doors. This will make her home more secure, since she spends most of her time teaching classes. The money will also allow her to plaster a room in her house. Her greatest dreams are for her children to become professionals who serve their country, and to be able to improve her house little by little, so that she can give her children the basic living conditions they deserve.

Translated from Spanish by Katie Kavanagh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy gates for the doors and to plaster a room

loans.name: Eliezer

texts.es:
Eliezer de 34 años de edad es casado con la Sra. Minerva Gudiel con quien tiene un hijo,  Eliezer trabaja para la Alcaldia Muncipal de Juigalpa desde hace 15 años, desempeñandose como  policia municipal. 

Esta solicitando  su 3er credito con el objetivo de construir un cuarto, ya cuenta con una parte de los materiales los cuales los compro con el financiamiento anterior, que con el apoyo de kiva se le otorgo , sin embargo necesita el financiamiento para terminar de comprar el cemento, hierro y el pago de la mano de obra. 

Elizer expresa sentirse muy agradecido con esta institucion, porque gracias a los creditos que se le han brindado a ido mejorando su vivienda. Su mayor sueño es poder brindarle a su familia una vivienda con las condiciones basicas para que vivan en un ambiente agradable.
texts.en:
Eliezer is 34 years old and married to Minerva Gudiel. They have one son together. Eliezer has been working as a policeman for the mayor's office in the municipality of Juigalpa for 15 years. Eliezer is requesting a loan so that he can complete construction on a room in his house. He already has some of the building materials needed which he purchased with a previous loan. However, he needs the new loan to purchase cement, iron, as well as pay for labor. Eliezer says he is very grateful for this institution, because thanks to the loans he has been able to improve the condition of his home. His greatest dream is to be able to provide his family with the basic living conditions to be comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for cement, iron and labor to finish construction on his house and provide a better environment for his family

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Pay for educational & personal expenses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase construction materials (zinc, iron, cement, etc.) & pay for labor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase zinc roofing & crossbeams

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy inventory, such as sandals, for her business

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.es:
El Grupo Renacer esta integrado por dos miembros, Sara Amileth C. H. y Jose Santos C. M., estan casados y tienen diferentes negocios.

Sara tiene 33 años de edad y Jose tiene 39, residen en la Aldea La Concepcion en Juticalpa, tienen tres hijos de 16,15 y 13 años de edad. Hace años atras comenzaron con una pequeña pulperia en su domicilio. Ahora ellos tambien cuentan con un pequeño local ubicado en la terminal de buses municipal y alli Jose vende todo tipo de frutas y verduras. Trabaja desde las 5:30 am hasta las 6:00 pm y su padre le enseño a trabajar. Sara atiende la pulperia en su domicilio todos los dias.

Los prestamos seran invertidos para la compra una gran varidad de frutas de la temporada y tambien verduras, lacteos, granos basicos como arroz, maiz y frijoles, pastas, salsas, condimientos, etc. Con los prestamos podran ofrecer a sus clientes mas y diferentes productos, y tambien tener mas ingresos para cubrir los gastos escolares de sus hijos y tambien para llevar el pan de cada dia a su hogar. 

Uno de los desafios que enfrentan es que el local donde Jose tiene el negocio de frutas y verduras no es propio y todos los meses deben pagar una renta mensual y en muchas ocasiones las ventas no son  muy buenas, pero cuenta con los ingresos de la pequeña pulperia de Sara que tiene en su domilicio y asi ayuda con la renta. 

Sus sueños son ver crecer a sus hijos sanos y que sean personas de bien y muy trabajadoras, tambien desean que el local donde funciona el negocio de frutas y verduras algun dia pueda llegar a ser suyos. 

Hace mas de 10 años son clientes de FAMA y gracias a los prestamos que han recibido cuentan con sus negocios actuales.
texts.en:
Sara Amileth C. H. is 33 years old. She lives in the small town of La Concepción. She married to José Cáceres and has three children who are 16, 15, and 13 years old. Three years ago she and her husband opened a small grocery store in their home. Now they also have a small store located in the municipal bus terminal where her husband sells all kinds of fruits and vegetables. She works from 5:30AM until 6:0PM. Her father taught her to work. The loan will be used to buy a large variety of seasonal fruits and also vegetables, dairy products, basic grains like rice, corn, and beans, pastas, sauces, condiments, etc. With this loan, she will be able to offer her customers more and different products. She will also have more income to use to cover the school costs for her children and also to feed her family. One of the challenges she faces is that the location where they have the fruit and vegetable business isn’t very good. Every month they have to pay rent and oftentimes sales aren’t very good. However, she can count on the income from the small grocery store she has in their home, and that way she can help her husband. Her dream is to see her children grow up healthy and for them to be professionals and very hardworking. She also hopes that the location where they have the fruit and vegetable business can someday belong to them. She has been a client with FAMA for 10 years and it is thanks to the loans that she has received that she has her current business.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, corn, beans, etc.

texts.es:
Doña Arely Sugey C. P. es comerciante,  soltera tiene un hijo menor de edad vive junto a su familia en el barrio San Agustín, su pequeño negocio de elaboración y venta de alimentos opera desde hace trece años en su casa de habitación.
   
La razón por la que actualmente está solicitando el crédito es para invertirlo directamente en la compra de la materia prima para continuar realizando los deliciosos alimentos y así seguir adelante en su actividad.
texts.en:
Arely Sugey C. P. is a merchant. She is single, has a small son, and lives with her family in the neighborhood of San Agustín. She has been operating her small business out of her home for three years. Arely has worked with Kiva partner CEPRODEL for two years, and has had twenty loans during that time, each of which was repaid in two months. These loans have enabled Arely to maintain her business and provide stability for her family. The loans have also enabled her to improve her home.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina started her house-cleaning business four years ago in her hometown in Massachusetts, supporting her family who live both in the United States and in Brazil. Gina has no employees and her husband and son both work at different companies. Four years ago Gina started her house-cleaning business because she saw that the cleaning business was strong in the U.S. She saw the opportunity to grow in this area by starting a business in her hometown. Now, she hopes to gain more clients by using her first ACCION USA loan to advertise her business. She plans to make her services more visible in the surrounding area because there is a large population she has not yet targeted. Gina loves being her own boss and having that personal contact with her clients. Her greatest challenge was having the courage to start her own business. Now, she is confident enough in her service and day-to-day operations that she wants to further grow her clientele. About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA: Have you ever thought about how the cute new café on your corner or the salon you frequent every month got the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated ten million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis”. Microfinance institutions, like ACCION USA, support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education. Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild our economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To advertise her house-cleaning business in the community

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia B. is a married woman who lives in Juan Luna, Poblacion, Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a tocino (cured meat) stand and a peanut-butter business. Her husband Feloteo B., who is 49 years old, works as a general contractor to earn his living. They have five children children who are between 15 and 25 years old. Virginia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past three loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Virginia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. By using her previous loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) as additional capital, she was able to increase her monthly profit to PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fourth loan cycle, she is borrowing PHP 13000, which she intends to add to her working capital for her businesses so that she can continue to save up for their future household expenses and for the education of their children. Virginia B. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.name: Krishna

texts.en: This is 40-year-old Krishna A.. She is married and has four children aged 16, 22, 20, and 18. In 2010, Krishna established a livestock business. Working seven days a week and sixteen hours a day, she supports her family. Krishna has already received and successfully repaid one loan from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to purchase feed for her livestock. In the future, she plans to promote and expand her business. Krishna hopes to take future loans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support. About Patan BPW: This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner in Nepal: micro-finance institution, Patan Business and Professional Women (Patan BPW). Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. It operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. With a Kiva loan, Patan BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer, which enables them to grow cash crops to sell in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our Patan BPW partner page to keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates. Also, please join our Patan BPW Lending Team.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed

loans.name: Bipana

texts.en:
Twenty-eight-year-old Bipana B., a married mother of two children aged 10 and 7 months, established her tea shop business this year. Working seven days a week for seven hours each day enables her to support her family. Bipana has already received and repaid a loan from BPW which she used to increase her store's inventory. In the future, she plans to promote and expand her business, and she thanks you for your support.

Whether on the streets of Kathmandu or in the villages outside of the capital, tea shops are places of business and meeting in Nepal. Called a chiya pasal, these tea shops make a sweet, milky tea that can be purchased for a few cents a cup. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to keep their store shelves stocked while increasing their profit margins by buying in greater volume.

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner, MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Operating throughout the Kathmandu Valley, it offers microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to its clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.

For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.name: Kalpana

texts.en:
This is 33-year-old Kalpana K.c.  She is married and has one child, aged 17.  In 2010, she established her farming business.  Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from BPW and used her most recent loan to produce vegetables.  In the future, Kalpana plans to promote her farming business.  She hopes to get a larger loan.  She thanks you for your support.

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural.  Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land.  Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (tarkari) are the staples of the Nepali diet.  With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market.  Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team.
