loans.name: Leopolda

texts.en:
Leopolda S. is from the town of Poblacion 4, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old. Leopolda is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Leopolda owns and operates a transportation service. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motor transport services. Leopolda has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leopolda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leopolda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. Leopolda is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to repair existing vehicles for better service. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Leopolda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Emily is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP with which she will purchase additional inventory and use for working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Emily from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn M. is from the town of Tinglan, Mutia, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 41 years old. Marilyn is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn owns & operates a business harvesting coconut for sale. Marilyn is just starting this business.

In 2006, Marilyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from PMPC. Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to acquire a parcel of land. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Marilyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To acquire a parcel of land

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie B. is from the village of Nangcaan, Rizal. She is 31 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rosemarie owns & operates a business venture in the transportation sector operating a motorcycle.  Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosemarie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used for personal purposes. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase spare parts for the unit. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Rosemarie from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for the motorcycle

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en: Mrs. Mary Jane L. is from Barangay I, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 25 years of age and is married to Leandro, a staff member of MOELCI II (Misamis Occidental II Electric Cooperative, Inc.), Ozamiz City. She is blessed with one child who is still an infant. Mary Jane is presently engaged in operating a fast food and grocery store business and is also receiving support from her husband. She’s been engaged in this kind of business for three years already and earns approximately 10,000 Php a month. Just this year, 2010, Mary Jane joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. As a newly recognized member of PMPC under its regular loan program, she is requesting a loan of 50,000 Php as her first loan to be used as additional capital for her fast food and grocery store business. Mary Jane plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs; in savings for future use and for her child’s education; and for loan repayments, insurances and possible business expansion. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her fast food and grocery store business

loans.name: Jessie Malinao's Group

texts.en: Jessie M. is from the village of Buenavista, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old and is the group leader of this two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if they are delinquent or default. The official name of this borrowing group is Jessie M.'s Group. Jessie is married and has five adult children. She owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2005, Jessie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jessie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Sotera

texts.en: Sotera S. is from the village of Upper Inuman, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 68 years old and is married with seven adult children. Sotera owns and operates a food stall selling banana cue (deep-fried banana covered with caramelized brown sugar). She has been engaged in her business for five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Sotera joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to cook. Sotera is requesting a new loan of 2,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital to buy more bananas to cook

loans.name: Min's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Min E. is 57 years old and is the village bank president, having been selected by its fifteen members. They are located in Meun Trea village, Kandal province. The members of this group loan will use the funds to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purpose.

Mrs. Min E. is a farmer who works very hard to support her two children. On the farm she owns a 1-hectare piece of land on which she cultivates rice that she sells, for a living. In order to support this farm, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for farming laborers. Mrs. Min E. is widow with two children, both are seamstresses in the garment factory.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for farming labor.

loans.name: Rothny's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Rothny S. is 49 years old and is this group's leader, having been selected by its four members, located in Kampong Dar village, Kandal province. The members of this group loan hope to increase their incomes in order to improve their family's standards of living. 

Mrs. Rothny S. and her husband, Mr. Touch Yarn, are farmers who own a plot of land on which to cultivate rice. With their farm, they work very hard to support their five children. In order to increase their income to improve the family's standard of living, Mrs. Rothny S. will use the loan to buy piglets and pig food for pig breeding. This couple has five children; one is a mechanic and two are laborers, while the other two are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food for pig breeding.

loans.name: Vannak

texts.en: Mrs. Vannak C. is 30 years old and she is a villager who lives in Kaoh Reah Leu village, Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Symon Choeun, are fruit sellers who are able to earn a small profit to support their family's living expenses. In order to support this business and in order to increase their income to improve the family's standard of living, Mrs. Vannak C. has decided to ask for a loan. With the loan she will buy more fruit to sell and rent some land to cultivate papaya. This couple has three children: one is attending in the local school while the other two are too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell and to rent some land to cultivate papaya.

loans.name: Puthy's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Puthy Y. 42 years old and is the group leader, having been selected by its five members located in Preak Tapov village, Kandal province. She is a farmer who works very hard to support her family's costs of living. Her husband, a motorbike taxi driver, is able to earn a small income to support his family's living expenses. Mrs. Puthy Y. now is requesting for a loan to dig a well and to pay for laborers to plow her farm so that she can grow corn, pumpkin and vegetables. This couple does not have any children.

loans.use: To dig a well and to pay for laborers to plow her farm to grow corn and pumpkin.

loans.name: Ofemia

texts.en:
Ofemia D. is a 61-year-old member of ASHI, KIVA’s first field partner in the Philippines. The woman lives with only her husband because all of her children have their own families now. Nevertheless, the couple is thankful that their children and grandchildren also live in their community. At least they are accessible to visit and to help them when they are in need.

To survive from her and her husband’s own efforts, Ofemia doesn’t like to be dependent on her children for they, like her, are also poor. Instead, she and her husband, who still works as a hired farm laborer, raise hogs and cattle which they sell when they are grown.

Hogs take four months until they are ready for selling while the cattle take a year. Hogs are sold either slaughtered or alive to people within their village while cattle, just like a large volume of live hogs, most often are sold alive directly to people who come to the marketplace.

Although Ofemia earns a profit once her animals are sold, the old woman feels it hard to sustain their everyday needs and to support the financial needs of her grandchildren. With that realization, she is requesting a much larger loan to finance the sustainability of her two businesses and to put up a small store in front of her house so that she can sell foodstuffs and vegetables. She will also be the one managing this business while she also looks after her hogs and cattle in the backyard.

loans.use: To purchase more cattle and piglets to raise. A small portion will be used to purchase inventory for her new store

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita S. is from the village of Centro Norte, Alcala, Cagayan. She is 53 years old and is married with four adult children.

Teresita owns and operates a general store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Ken's Group

texts.en:
Mr. K. K., 62 years old, is the group leader, having been selected by its four members located in Beoung Voucher village, Kandal province. The members of this group loan will use the funds to support their different purposes.

Mr. K. K. is a farmer own owns 2.50-hectares of land and owns a plowing machine to grow rice and corn. His wife, Mrs. Soeung Lim, stays at home and takes care of her children. With the farm, Mr. K. K. decided to ask for a loan to buy two wheels for his plowing machine. Aside from farming, Mr. K. K. is also fisherman who is able to earn a small income to support his family. This couple has three children: one is a farmer and one is a seamstress in a garment factory while the last one is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy two wheels for plowing machine.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en: Juanita M. is from the town of Centro Norte, Alcala, Cagayan. She is 35 years old and is married with one school-aged child. Juanita owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,100 PHP a month. Juanita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira V. is from the village of Centro Norte, Alcala, Cagayan. She is 42 years old and is married with three school-aged children.

Elvira owns and operates a restaurant, serving lunch foods to customers in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twleve years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

Elvira joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase food and drinks for her restaurant. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

Seen in the picture with Elvira is the ASKI Credit Officer who is helping her in the processing of her loan. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food and drinks for her restaurant

loans.name: Set's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Set P. is 63 years old and is the group leader, having been selected by its four members located in Koh Chamroeun village, Kandal province. Each member of this group loan will use it to buy equipment, supplies and other items to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Set P. and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate vegetable for a living. With this farm, they are also working very hard to support their family living. For this farm, Mrs. Set P. will use the loan that he has requested from AMK to buy fertilizer and pesticide to help cultivate rice. This couple has a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Thon's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thon P. is 39 years old and is the group leader, having been selected by its four members located in Ampil Toek village, Kandal province. Each member of this group loan will use it to support their different purposes.
 
Mrs. Thon P. is a farmer and she also is a vegetable seller who works very hard to support her four children. Her husband, Mr. Phouk Soun, is a fisherman who is able to earn a small income to support his family's living costs. For vegetable selling, Mrs. Thon P. decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to expand her business activities. This couple has four children: three are seamstresses in the garment factory and the last one is a student.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to expand her business activities.

loans.name: Penh's Group

texts.en:
Four people are making up a group loan located in Lekh Mouy village, Kandal province. Mrs. Penh P. is 45 years old and is the group leader of the loan, having been selected by its members. With the loans, the members of this group hope to increase their incomes to improve their families standards of living.

Mrs. Penh P. stays at home and she also takes care of her children. Her husband, Mr. Sam Oeun Tes, is a construction foreman who is able to earn a small profit to support his family's living expenses. Mrs. Penh P. now is requesting for a loan to add her savings to build a house. This couple has five children: two are seamstresses in the garment factory and one is a vegetable seller while the other two are attending in the local school.

loans.use: To add her savings to build a house.

loans.name: Crema

texts.en: Crema A. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Liloan, Santander, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: shell craft and food vending. Her husband, Hermogenes A., who is 48 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living. They have four children who are from 17 to 25 years old. Crema joined NWTF-Project Dungganon six years ago because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past sixteen loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 5,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 17th loan, Crema is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use in her shell-craft business so that she can continue to save for the future and send her children to school, especially to college. Crema is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva and become a part of our team.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Sophat's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people located in Ampil Teouk village, Kandal province. Mrs. Sophat S., 60 years old, is the leader of this group loan, having been selected by its members. Each member of this group loan will use it to support their different purposes.  

Mrs. Sophat S. is a congee seller (rice porridge) and she is also a coffee seller who is able to earn a small income to support her child. Mrs. Sophat S. is now requesting for a loan to add her savings to fix her house. Mrs. Sophat S. is a widow with a child who is a laborer.

loans.use: To fix her house.

loans.name: Hourn

texts.en:
Hourn T., 32, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples.

T. and her husband weave Cambodian traditional silk for an income of USD 4 each per day to help cover the family expenses. T. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase cows to raise for resale.

In the future, T. would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy cows to raise and sell

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed is the wife of A. R. and they live in a city called Borewala in Pakistan. Borewala is famous for its shrines. Khursheed has given birth to three children: one daughter and two sons. Her daughter is married and her sons are still studying. The family lives in a small house.

Khursheed earns income by making bicycle seat covers to order. She is a very vigorous lady who always wanted to work to share the financial burden with her husband and to stand with him. She makes seat covers by using leather and soft foam to make the seat comfortable for sitting.

Khursheed is very happy to mention that, with her income, she has been able to marry her daughter. Her husband feels proud on her in this regard, too.

Khursheed’s husband operates a clothes-selling business and has been doing this work for over six years. Khursheed is applying for her second loan from Asasah to expand her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy more clothes to increase his sales.

In this photo, the two members, Naheed and Musarat, are showing the handmade fans that they make.

loans.use: To enable her husband to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Heikly's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Heikly T. is 60 years old and is the village bank president. This group consists of eight members located in Prek Be village in Kandal province. The members of this village loan will use the funds to support their different purposes.
 
Mrs. Heikly T. and her husband, Mr. Pavhy Tae, are farmers who work very hard to support their family's standard of living. With the farm, they own a plot of land to grow sapota (a tree fruit resembling plum or pear) for a living. In order to support this farm, Mrs. Heikly T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to grow sapotas. With the rest of the loan she wants to buy lamps and batteries for an electric machine. This couple has a child who is a farmer and also helps in the parents' businesses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Ing

texts.en:
Ing N., 33, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She works at a local garment factory for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband, who appears in the photograph, is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 4 per day.

N. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy a new motorbike for his business

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en: Visitacion T. is from the town of Centro Norte, Alcala, Cagayan. She is 47 years old and is married with one infant child. Visitacion owns and operates a general store, selling children's products such as toys and games in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. Visitacion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Men K., 68, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She is a housewife, while her husband is a village chief earning an income of USD 1 per day. Her is child is currently employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses.  K. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a new motorbike for her child to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida, the wife of M. A., is a resident of Borewala, a city in Pakistan famous for its shrines. A very caring lady, Zubaida is always ready to help family members and friends in the community. Living with her in-laws, she does her best to give them happiness as she feeds and takes care of them. All feel good to have her in their lives.

Her husband sells clothes in her neighborhood and in the market, purchasing his products from two cities, Faisalabad and Lahore, the latter famous for its textiles. He buys from these cities because they offer good quality materials and designs.

Zubaida is now requesting a loan from Asasah to enable her husband to buy clothes in bulk to increase his sales and earn additional profits.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for reselling

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim S., 36, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. (S.'s husband appears in the photograph.) 

She is a garment-factory worker, earning an income of $2 per day. Her husband grows hay and mushrooms and raises chickens, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase a new motorbike to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike to commute to work

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
A hardworking mother and wife, Anita Sta. M. dreams of having their own fishing boat so that her husband, who is a fisherman, will have his own means for fishing and have bigger earnings than working with other people financing his business. With this, the woman who handles the cash flow for her family would be able to have a strong financial source to support their needs, as well as to support the immediate needs of her six children and their own family members. Someday, she hopes that through the business she has been able to grow, she can help improve their lifestyle, especially that of her grandchildren.  

With the loan Anita is requesting presently, she believes that a step to achieving her above mentioned desires will be undertaken. She will purchase a motorboat for fishing. That way, she will have more fish to sell directly to people within their village and in the neighboring villages. Her selling activity would also be more regular because her husband’s time wouldn’t be controlled by other people or an employer perhaps.

loans.use: To purchase a motorboat for fishing

loans.name: Gantulga

texts.en:
Gantulga G. lives with his wife and two teenage children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. He drives a cab in the town. His oldest children attend secondary school, while his youngest daughter stays at home with his mother. His wife Saruul is a professional hairdresser.

He has been doing the taxi business since 2005. Gantulga is a very hardworking person and is known for his good character. He is working hard to maintain his success and has much hope for the future. He needs to keep his car in good condition so that he can continue to earn a living. Therefore, he is requesting a 1,300,000 tugrug loan in order for him to make the necessary repairs and to replace parts on his car.

loans.use: To repair his car

loans.name: Chong's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chong D. is 53 years old and is the leader of a group loan, having been selected by its four members located in Prek Ta In village, Kandal province. With the loan, the members of this group will purchase supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes.
   
Mrs. Chong D. and her husband, Mr. Khoeun Sa, are fishermen who are able to earn a small income to support their family's living costs. For this fishing, Mrs. Chong D. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fish nets to support her fishing. This couple has a child who is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets.

loans.name: Kroch

texts.en:
Kroch V., 36, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She sells food for an income of USD 3 per day, while her husband, a construction worker, earns an income of USD 3 per day.

Kroch is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase a place at a national tourist site in her province from which to sell her food. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a place at a national tourist site from which to conduct food sales

loans.name: Catarino

texts.en: Catarino G. is from the village of San Roque, Enrile, Cagayan. He is 45 years old. Catarino is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Catarino provides transportation services. The main source of income for the business comes from operating a motorcycle-transport service. Catarino has been engaged in his business for more than two years and earns approximately 5,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Catarino joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Catarino has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. Catarino is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be the third loan taken out by Catarino from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

texts.en: Tri S., 30, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. Sokheang is requesting a loan of $400 to grow more rice. In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.name: Oun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. OU. K. is 38 years old and is the village bank president, having been selected by its twelve members that are located in Preak Thmei village, Kandal province. Each member of this group loan will use it to support their different purposes.

Mrs. OU. K. is a flower seller in the local market while her husband, Mr. Tum Tuy, is a construction foreman who is able to earn a small profit to help support his family's living expenses. In order to support the flower business, Mrs. OU. K. will use the loan that she has requested from AMK to buy more flowers to sell. This couple has four children: two are attending the local school and the other two are too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy more flowers.

loans.name: Pat

B. is requesting a loan of $1100 to purchase more groceries for resale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Rufina T. is from the village of Katutungan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 44 years old. Rufina is married and has nine school-aged children. Rufina owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from producing and selling boiled duck eggs or balot in the local community. Rufina has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Rufina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 7000 PHP and was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Rufina is now requesting her sixth loan from HSPFI, for 10,000 PHP, which will be used to to purchase additional inventory & as working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. The main source of income for the business comes from hauling plastics & other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Adelina has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2005, Adelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Adelina has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Adelina is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional plastics & other recyclables to sell. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Adelina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia P. is from the village of Wadya, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 58 years old. Lydia is widowed and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lydia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products, and also selling electronic loads for cell phone users in the local community. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Lydia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and provide working capital. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Lydia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Arnold has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP whenever he sells his raised animal.

Arnold joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arnold has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. Arnold is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Arnold from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Azizan's Group

texts.en:
Azizan is the mother of three children and the wife of M. R.. She is a housewife and stays at home to take care of her family. Her two sons work. They couldn’t get education due to financial constraints. Her eldest son is a tailor and the younger one works in a clothes mill. Her elder son has three years of experience in the tailoring business and sews clothes very well.
 
This family of five people lives in a three room cement house in a city named Borewala in Pakistan. Azizan has taken three loans from ASASAH and successfully repaid them. Every year she has maintained good credit behavior. With the profits from these three loans she purchased a cooking range for her kitchen to cook food easily for her family. Her daughter also supports her in cooking food.

Now she is applying for the fourth loan from Asasah for her elder son. He will buy an electric sewing machine with the loan and increas his earnings by sewing more clothes. 

This is a group loan.

Note: In this photo, Imtiaz (a group member) is showing her artificial flowers which she makes and sells by herself.

loans.use: To purchase an electric sewing machine for tailoring business.

loans.name: Sothy's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Sothy B. is a 24 year old married man and he is the group leader of this loan, having been selected by its four members located in Koh Krabei village, Kandal province. Each member of this group loan will use it to support their different purposes.
 
Mr. Sothy B. and his wife, Mrs. Channy Chany, are flower sellers who are able to earn a small profit to support their family's living expenses. With this business, Mr. Sothy B. will use the loan that he has requested from AMK to buy more flowers to expand his business activities. Aside from flower sellers, they are also laborers. They receive a small salary to add their savings to improve the family's standard of living. This couple has a child who is too young to study or work.

loans.use: To buy more flowers.

In order to support the farm, Mrs. Chan Meak K. will use the loan she has requested from AMK to buy fertilizer to cultivate vegetables. With the rest of the loan, she wants to buy more vegetables to support her husband's business. This couple has four children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other three are students and also support their parents' businesses.

Siman is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to transport beef. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.name: Sokhouy's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of nine people which located I. Bang Village, Kandal province. Mrs. Sokhouy C. is 35 years old and is the village bank president having selected by its members. While each member of this village loan will use it to support their different purpose. 
Mrs. Sokhouy C. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. For this farm, she will use the loan to purchase fertilizer to cultivate rice. Aside from farmer she is also grocery seller who is able to earn a small income to support her family living, while her husband, Mr. Phally Haem, is a primary school director and also support his wife businesses. This couple has three children, who all are students I. the local school.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer to cultivate rice

loans.name: Sokna's Group

texts.en:
Mr. Sokna P. is a 27 year old married man and is the group leader of the loanhaving been selected by its four members which located in Chrolong village in Kandal province. While each member of this group loan will use it to support their different purpose.
Mr. Sokna P. is a famer who works very hard to support his family living. In order to support this farm, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for farming laborer to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. Sina Kann, is a seamstress in a garment factory where he can receive a small salary to support her family living. This couple has two children, one is a student and another one is 4 years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for farming laborer to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Rubina's Group

texts.en:
Rubina does not work herself, but her mother and her brother does. They live in the same house. Her mother is a seamstress by profession, while her brother is a mason but he also knows how to drive. He drives a rented rickshaw part-time to generate extra income.
 
Rubina helps her mother complete the orders of her customers. She sews clothes with her and completes them on time, which helps her mother to receive a reasonable income from her customers and more sewing orders.

Rubina is applying for a loan for the first time from Asasah for her brother. With the loan amount he will buy his own rickshaw and take on this profession full time. This will help him to improve his and his family's financial conditions.

loans.use: To purchase a rickshaw.

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Yen P., 37, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She weaves Cambodian traditional silk for an income of USD 2.50 per day. Her husband is employed by a company to break stone, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Yen P. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase more raw silk to produce more silk products. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more raw silk.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Matluba's Group

texts.en:
Matluba E. is the leader of the group. She is 29 and married. She has a son and a daughter, the son is a student and the daughter is not yet. Matluba’s husband works in construction, and from time to time he goes to Russia to work there. Four years ago, Matluba’s farther presented her a calf, and since that moment she has bred cattle. From selling the milk and some cattle after fattening, she makes 3,000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan, Matluba wants to purchase a bull, which she is going to sell at a higher price after fattening. In the future she wants to increase the number of cattle and finish the construction of their new house.

Edgarhon M., 32, is married. She has two daughters and a son, the daughters are students and the son is not yet. Edgarhon’s husband went to work in Russia to make some money, as he works as a constructor. Two years ago, with the initial investment of 5,000 soms, Edgarhon started to grow sunflowers, and she has applied for a loan because she needs money to purchase fertilizers for farming.

Muslima G. is the treasurer of the group. She is 33 and married. She has two daughters, the first daughter is six and the second is four.  Muslima’s husband works as a constructor, and he earns 5,000 soms per month. Seven years ago, with the initial investment of 20,000 soms, Muslima started to breed cattle. All the money which she makes from selling the harvest she invests in cattle breeding. From the sale of animals after fattening, Muslima makes 3,000 soms per month. With the money received from the loan she wants to purchase a calf for breeding.

Hairullo A., 35, is married. He has two sons, the first son is a student and the second is not yet. Hairullo has been engaged in cattle breeding for twenty years. He started with the initial investment of 15,000 soms, and now he makes 3,000 soms per month. Hairullo applied for the loan because he needs money to purchase a bull, which he is going to sell at a higher price after fattening. In the future he wants to increase the number of cattle, to be able to pay for his children’s education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To purchase a bull.

loans.name: Nhorn

texts.en: Nhorn M., 28, is married and resides with her husband and a young child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She is employed at a local garment factory for an income of USD 2.50 per day. Her husband transports water to supply his village, and he is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 7 per day. Nhorn M. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a trailer to transport water for the people in the village. In the future, she would like to use any additional profits to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a trailer to transport water supply.

loans.name: Suraiya's Group

texts.en:
Suraiya is the wife of N. A.. They have three sons and live in a two room brick house in a city called Borewala in Pakistan.

N. and his eldest son sell blankets to various places in the community. They also sell in different cities such as Islamabad and Lahore, where people buy blankets in advance of the winter season. N. has been doing this business for over twenty years, but his son joined him in his business five years ago.  

Suraiya is also a very hard working lady. She stays at home and manages the household chores, but she also operates her own sewing business. Her clientele base is her neighbors. She receives orders from them and earns a good income from the business. 

Suraiya has taken three loans from ASASAH and successfully repaid them. She has maintained good credit behavior. Now she is applying for the fourth loan so she can expand the business of her husband. 

With the loan he will buy more blankets and increase his sales.

loans.use: To purchase blankets for reselling.

This couple has three children, who all are seamstresses in the garment factory.

loans.name: Chem

texts.en: Chem C., 43, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She is a farmer, growing rice and raising pigs for an income of $1 (US) per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of $3 (US) per day. C. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda N. is from the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 59 years old. Erlinda is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products and also having a mini-eatery in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Erlinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Erlinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital for her "sari-sari" store

loans.name: Fozia's Group

texts.en:
Fozia is the mother of three children and the wife of Mr. S.. This small family lives in a three room brick house in a city of Pakistan named Borewala. Borewala City is famous for its shrines. 

Fozia and her husband have their own work. Fozia is a seamstress and her husband is a government servant. Fozia has ten years of experience in her domestic-sewing business. She does this work to financially support her husband because in government sector the wages are insufficient. She has a good reputation among her customers. In the past she sewed clothes of her neighbors, but later on her work become famous in the market, and now she gets the order from the boutiques as well. 
  
Fozia is a second year member of Asasah. She successfully repaid her first loan and maintained a good credit behavior as well. Now she is applying for her sewing business. She will buy another sewing machine for her business because her daughter also wants to support her in her business. With her help she can increase her business and earn a good profit.

loans.use: Purchase another sewing machine for the sewing business

loans.name: Zhyldyzgul's Group

texts.en:
Zhyldyzgul K. is the leader of the group. She is 45 and married. She has raised two daughters and a son. The older daughter and the son are married, and they live separately with their families. The second daughter is just three years old. In order to make money Zhyldyzgul sells fruits and vegetables, and her husband works as a constructor. Selling the fruits, Zhyldyzgul makes 11500 soms per month and the initial investment in that business activity was 3000 soms. With money received from the loan Zhyldyzgul wants to purchase more fruits and vegetables in order to resell them with the higher price. In the future she plans to build a new house in Bishkek.

Aiymbubu A. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 53 and a widow. She works as teacher at school and at the same time she makes and sells samsa (national food). She has been doing it for five years. In this way she makes 10000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase furniture.

Mahabat O., 27, is married.  She has a daughter who is just one year old. Mahabat stays at home and takes care of her daughter, and her mother-in-law breeds cattle and resells it for making money. With money received from the loan Mahabat wants to purchase clothes in order to resell them and make some money.

Altymyshbek A., 40, is married. He has a daughter and two sons, and all of them study at university. Four years ago with the initial investment of 5000 soms Altymyshbek started to breed cattle. Selling some cattle after fattening he makes 21000 soms per month.  He applied for the loan because he needs money to purchase hay for cattle. In the future he wants to build a new house in Bishkek.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegetables for reselling them

loans.name: Nilma's Group

texts.en:
Nilma A. is from the town of gabunon tambulig. She is 28 years old. Nilma is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Nilma is married and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Nilma owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as eggs, noodles, soft drinks, shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Nilma has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nilma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. Nilma is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Nilma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Khursheeda's Group

texts.en:
Khursheeda is the wife of M. R. and the mother of three children, one daughter and two sons. She has a business of making seat covers. She makes beautiful covers by applying good and different designs, and people come to her to buy the seat covers for their cycles.

Her one daughter is married and her sons are still studying. This family lives in a small house in Borewala, Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines.

She happily mentioned that her earnings allowed her to marry off her daughter. She has given all the necessary items to her daughter with her savings. 

She is a second year member of Asasah. She maintained good credit behavior in the first year of her loan and successfully returned the loan. Now, she is applying for her business again. With the loan amount she will buy the necessary items such as leather and thread in bulk, to make more seat covers and generate good profits from the sales.

Note: In this photo, Sugran, a group member, is showing her clothes sales business.

loans.use: To purchase required items for cycle seat cover production.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy Q. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. She has been involved in farming for seven years already. She helps her husband maintain their rice farm and sell their harvest to the market. A few years back, she opened a small bake shop located at their house. She says she and her husband decided to venture into this kind of business so they would have another source of income that would sustain their family, especially their children's education. 

Daisy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daisy has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Daisy is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment and also supplies for her bake shop. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Daisy from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Timoi Ole

texts.en:

This will be his first loan which he is planning to spend on harrowing, buying seeds, and planting his five acres of wheat. He hopes to use the profits from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

Timoi’s dream is to do large scale farming and buy his own farm machinery. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.name: Flor

texts.en:
Fifty-two-year-old Flor V. has been a member of ASHI, (the first KIVA field partner in the Philippines) since 1999. Her determination to ensure that her three children graduate from college and to improve the family's lifestyle has inspired her to have faith and work hard. Throughout her membership in ASHI, she has maintained an excellent performance in terms of her loan repayments, attendance at weekly center meetings and rice production in her farming business, thereby ensuring that the entire amount she requests from ASHI is granted to her. With the support of her loving husband, Gerardo, who is a farmer, Flor has been able to earn additional proceeds with which to finance the education of her children. Thus far, her two eldest children have graduated, while Flor continues to sustain the education of her youngest in college.

Although Flor has only one child left in college, she still has the responsibility of supporting the whole family because her two graduated children are not yet employed and so are without their own sources of income. As well, her husband had a stroke recently, leaving half of his body paralyzed and his productivity severely limited. Despite concern for her husband and her entire family, Flor took the opportunity to discover her own productive capabilities for their survival. She is requesting a much larger loan than usual through ASHI to support the increasing financial demands of her rice production since she must now hire a farm laborer to perform the tasks formerly done by her husband.

After harvest, Flor will have to wholesale their rice to have something to re-invest for the next cropping (planting) season, which is twice a year, and for the tuition fees of her child in college. She also has to support the medicines needed by her husband to ensure that he recovers and then maintains his health.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs such as fertlizers and seedlings, and to pay for a hired laborer.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 57-year-old married man and father of one child who is attending high school. He has owned a blacksmith shop in Lebanon since 1984. He has a large experience in this profession and over the years he has gained a strong reputation and a good number of clients. He is the main provider of his family with his business. With his loan request for US $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. , he wants to replace and repair the equipment he uses for his work in addition of purchasing a special tool to cut iron. He hopes that it will help develope his business and earn more profit to be able to continue satisfying his family needs and paying to finish his child's high school and continue on to  university. His main objective is to see his only child graduating from university that why he works hard.                                                                       

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 24-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his family and 2 siblings. Despite his young age, he has been an experienced carpenter for almost 10 years. And in 2005, he has owned his shop in his town. He is requesting his loan of US $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new equipment for his business and additional wood supplies to sell. He will able to make a variety of products and satisfy the demands of his clients, increasing his sales and his profit by a large percentage.  

In the future, he is looking to further expand his merchandise and invest in a new wood-sanding machine. He hopes that the coming year will continue to bring positive growth and increased sales. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.About Ameen:

Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: purchase new equipment for his work and additional supplies of wood to sell

loans.name: Baljinnyam

texts.en:
Baljinnyam B. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Tosontsengel city of Zavhan province, western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband, Batsaihan, is an ambulance driver while her both children are students in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They have been living together in their current home for 12 years. 

Currently, Baljinnyam has been operating a meat trading business at a local market. She has been operating her business since 2006 with the help of her husband, and has steadily expanded her business. She started her business with a working capital of 200,000 MNT. After years of successful operations Baljinnyam has increased her working capital to 1,800,000 MNT.  She is an open-minded person and has many plans for the future. She says, “I would like to expand my business and to produce meat products, which are closer to my profession as a chef.” She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase large amount of livestock in order to slaughter and sell at retail prices.

Mrs. Sareoun S. stays at home and takes care of her children while her husband, Mr. V. Leang, is a motorcycle taxi driver who is able to earn a small income to support his family living. 
Mrs. Sareoun S. now is requesting for a loan to add her saving to fix her house. This couple has six children; three are laborer one, is a security guard while the other two are students.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline is a 30-year-old young lady who operates a salon and lives in Hoima, Uganda. Jackline is married to a businessman. She takes care of her parents and she is currently residing in a rented house. She says building her own residential home is a dream she is working on. Jackline has been in the salon business for six years now. She says that constant power cutoffs affect her business since there are some clients she can’t handle without electricity. She says in the future, she hopes to sell only braids and cosmetics as her business. She intends to use the loan to purchase hair braids and cosmetics for her salon business.

loans.use: To purchase hair braids and cosmetics

loans.name: Banzragch

texts.en: Banzragch C. is 53 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Tosontsengel, a city of Zavhan province, western Mongolia. His wife operates a clothing sewing business and his elder son works in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia while the youngest son attends a local middle school. The family has been living in their current home for 22 years. Banzragch makes iron items in his own shop near the family home. He started this business in 1995 and has since made quality products for the people of his province. He has found out the advantage of his business is that there are very few people in his province operating an ironsmith business supplying local citizens with ironwork products. Banzragch also wants to expand his business by making more products and further improve his family’s financial situation and the quality of life. Banzragch is a very modest person. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy more iron and welding products for his business.

loans.name: Bwagonga Abamwe, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Lydia T. is a hardworking and ever optimistic 29-year-old married mother of three children aged between 3 and 8 years. She operates a growing produce business in the Bwagoga Trading Centre in Ibanda, dealing in dry food and cereals. With a business longevity span of eight years, Lydia has managed to significantly sustain and improve on her family’s welfare status through her contributions to paying the school dues for her children and more. 

To all appearances, her future business prospects look rosy, with close to 50,000 Ugandan shillings coming in monthly out of her business. She envisions an even greater profit margin as she gets this loan, anticipating being in position to buy more stock for the business. This will enable her business to expand and also enable her to earn more revenue and live a self-sustaining life.

With the 40,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase iron sheets and timber for roofing for her rental houses. In addition, she earns her other source of livelihood from her other business of selling second-hand clothes. 

Masika faces the major challenge of competition from other food-stall operators in the community. She hopes to build three more rental houses in the future. Her main aim of working with Yehu is because of its sustainable financial services to rural entrepreneurs. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Currently, Nergui operates a taxi service in his town. He has been operating his business since 2002 and has gained much experience over the years. He transports people according to regulations in Narantuul, the biggest market to Hailaast, northern of Ulaanbaatar by a micro-bus. Nergui is a very hard working person and is known as a reliable lender of Xacbank. He has borrowed 3 loans and paid each back in full and on time.  He says, “My wife and I would like to meet our family's needs without help of our children and to improve the quality of my family's life.”  He is requesting a  4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a microbus for his business.

loans.name: Shakooran's Group

texts.en:
Shakooran lives in three room brick house in the city called Borewala in Pakistan. She is a widow and one of her sons earns income to support the family. He is the only breadwinner after his father. He owns & operates a food stand where he keeps the food such as (Nan Chanay and Payay) which people love to eat in breakfast. Shakooran helps him with cooking these items so that he can start selling them early in the morning. 

Shakooran wants to help her son in expanding his business because he is working very hard for his family. Shakooran is applying for a loan for her son who will buy food items such as chick peas, cooking oil and spices in bulk for his stall.

Shakooran is a second year member of Asasah, has successfully repaid her first loan and has a good record of repayment. With her first loan her son started his food stand and now with the loan amount he will increase his sales.

During the day, Uyanga operates a clothing trading business at Narantuul, the biggest and most crowded market in Ulaanbaatar city. Uyanga has been operating her business since 2001, and has steadily expanded her business and gained much experience in previous years. Her working capital has now reached to 5,000,000 MNT and the daily earning is from 50,000 to 60,000 MNT. Uyanga is a very hardworking person and her business is very important for her family. She says, “I would like to expand my business and own a shop in the future”. She is requesting a 3,100,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothing for her business.
