loans.name: Razelou

texts.en: Razelou Y. is a single woman who lives in Sitio Suba, Barangay Looc, Malabuyoc, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a gasoline retailing business. Razelou joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past twelve loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,256, thus, uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 13th loan, Razelou is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to expand her gasoline retailing business so that she can continue to save for her family and have additional savings for future use. Razelou is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

loans.name: Sajida Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Sajida perveen has spent all of her life in a small city called Borewala in Pakistan. She is the mother of two children but neither of them could get an education due to poor financial circumstances. Her husband is a motor mechanic and she supports her husband by doing domestic-sewing work. 

Sajida is applying for a loan from Asasah for her father who is involved in an animal-selling business. With the help of loan assistance, she is hopeful that her father will be able to increase his income by purchasing more animals and selling them for a profit.

This is Sajida’s fourth year with Asasah. In the last three years, Sajida has never given any complaints regarding repayments and has maintained a good credit behavior with Asasah. She is hopeful that this will also be a profitable experience for her family as always.

loans.use: To enable her father to purchase more animals to sell

loans.name: Na's Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people are making a village bank loan which located in Preaek Ta Mem village, Kandal province. Mrs. Na Tai is 41 years old and is a village bank president having been selected by its members. While each member of this group loan will use it to support their different purpose.
Mrs. Na Tai is a farmer who owns a plot of land and rent some piece of land to cultivate rice and peanut for a living. In order to support this farm, she decided to ask for a loan to pay for renting piece of land and to buy fertilizer to grow crops. Her husband, Mr. Lonh Bo, is a construction foreman who is able to receive a small salary to support his family living. This couple has three children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory and one is a construction worker while another one is a student in.

loans.use: To pay for renting piece of land and to buy fertilizer to grow crops.

loans.name: Cecille

texts.en: Cecille P. is from the village of Banlag, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 36 years old. Cecille is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Cecille operates a business selling firewood and charcoal in the local community. Cecille has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Cecille joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecille is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Cecille from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita E. is one of the very good members of ASHI in her village. Since her membership in 2005, she has been able to gain trust and good relationships with her co-members. Moreover, Teresita felt very thankful to ASHI because through it, she has able to gain self-confidence which has improved her ways of dealing with other people, especially in favor of her business. 

The loans she has taken support the growth of her business, while proceeds from her business support the needs of her two children, ages 19 and 23 years. Teresita’s husband is already dead; therefore, she has to achieve her dream of graduating her youngest child from college and support her eldest child until he will have his own stable source of income. For now, Doroteo, her eldest child, works as a hired laborer and is earning just a small amount of money. Somehow, it is such a great help for him to provide for some of his needs, but most of the time he is dependent on his mother just like his sister.

Sustainability of her fish-selling business is always the worry of Teresita because most of her income, including the supposed return of investment to her business, is used to support her family, as it is the only source of their livelihood. No matter how hard she carries her fish over head or in a basket held by her two hands to sell her fish directly to people in their houses, and village after village, still her income over the expenses of her family is insufficient. However, she is still hopeful that with the loans she can take through ASHI, her business will be sustainable and profitable until her child has graduated from college and their lives have improved and they are no longer poor.

loans.use: To purchase larger volume of fish for selling

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth P. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old. Ruth is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Ruth runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Ruth has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Ruth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Ruth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine C. is a 48-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: a small eatery (carinderia) and an electronic reloading businesses. She lives in Poblacion, Oslob, Cebu. 

Josephine has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her small eatery and electronic reloading businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP 20,000/month. 

Josephine is now borrowing PHP 29,500 to use as additional working capital for her small eatery. This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Josephine aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Edward

texts.en: Edward is a 36-year-old married man with two children aged 10 and 2. He has been operating his pharmacy for five years. He also farms to supplement his family’s income. Edward previously operated a cafeteria. He appreciates being a member of Faulu Kenya because he can afford to educate his children and has bought a piece of land. He is requesting a loan of 60,000 KES to open another pharmacy and a cafeteria.  He hopes to own a pharmaceutical company in the future.

loans.use: To open a pharmacy and a cafeteria

loans.name: Rwakahurwa Tukore, Rukungiri Group

texts.en: Hardworking widowed B. Peninah from Nyaruharo, Rukungiri started up her poultry farming business over five years ago. She was a lucky beneficiary of national agricultural programs here in Uganda that help people start up different projects. With her determination, she developed her business and sells eggs and broilers for chicken meat to hotels and other local consumers with shops that provide ready market. Her main drawback is having a small stock of birds. With this loan, she is very optimistic of increasing her stock of poultry birds and having more production in terms of eggs and broiler supplies. This will definitely improve her sales revenue and family income to enable her to provide for her 5 children’s welfare.

loans.use: restocking the poultry farm with more birds

loans.name: Leonard

texts.en: Leonard, a 30-year-old married man with two children, aged four and one, has been running a cafeteria for two years, employing two people to help him serve his customers.  He previously took out a loan of 80,000 KES, now repaid, to buy a plot of land, and is now requesting a new loan of 90,000 KES to buy cooking ingredients.  Leonard is a hardworking man who hopes to expand his business and open other outlets in the future.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for cooking

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Aurelia R. is a married woman who lives in GK Village, Brgy Villareal, Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a fish vending business.  

Aurelia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she hoped for something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Aurelia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, thus raising her family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 6th cycle loan, Aurelia is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her business in order to continue to save up for future renovations of her house. Aurelia R. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Wolale I Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE I  est un regroupement des femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 46  ans et au moins 8  enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide du fonio et du sésame. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe WOLALE I ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents qui étaient des prêts solidaires, elles sont à leur premier prêt de campagne.
MARTIN D. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de fonio, d’arachide,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN, DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe WOLALE I comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 29000 à 30000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Wolale I Group are married women living in Cinzara, a village in the prefecture of San in the region of Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 46 years old and have at least eight children. They grow groundnuts, fonio and sesame. In order to ensure that their agricultural investments are profitable, the members of Wolale I Group decided two years ago to participate in the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. After having properly repaid their previous loans, which were solidarity loans, they apply now for their first farming loan. Martin D. wants to use her loan to buy adequate quantities of fonio and groundnut seeds, small equipment and farming supplies at the great market in San. After the rainy season, the harvest will be warehoused long enough for its value to increase, before it is sold at the great market in San, in Dah and at the nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. After their produce is sold, the members of Wolale I Group expect to make a profit of 29,000 to 30,000 CFA francs each, which they will use to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy farming supplies, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Suraiya's Group

texts.en:
Suraiya is a housewife and a great mother who plays her part very effectively. She is a citizen of a city called Borewala, in Pakistan. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over 25 years. She has given birth to two kids: one daughter and one son.
  
Her husband is involved in the animal-selling business and her son, who is 22 years old, has a bike-rental business. They both work hard to manage the financial expenses of the family. Her daughter is 15 years old and helps her manage the household chores.
 
Suraiya is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband, who will buy goats for his animal-selling business. Suraiya is very hopeful about her family’s bright future. This is her fourth year to be with Asasah. She has maintained good credit behavior.

loans.use: Purchase animals for reselling

loans.name: Sherlita

texts.en: Sherlita D. is from the village of Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 66 years old. Sherlita is widowed and has six adult children. To make a living, Sherlita operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling spices like onion, garlic and tomatoes. Sherlita has been engaged in her business for more than eight years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Sherlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sherlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Sherlita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Sherlita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nena

texts.en: Nena M. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Nena is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Nena runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Nena has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Nena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nena is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Nena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Wolale Ii Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE II   est  constitué de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne 43 ans, 4  enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide, du fonio et du sésame. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents qui étaient des prêts solidaires, elles sont à leur premier prêt de campagne.
NANA T., compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de fonio, d’arachide,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles,  au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN, DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 26000 à 27000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Wolale II Group are married women living in Cinzara, a village in the prefecture of San in the region of Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 43 years old and have four children. They grow groundnuts, fonio and sesame. In order to ensure that their agricultural investments are profitable, the members of Wolale I Group decided two years ago to participate in the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. After having properly repaid their previous loans, which were solidarity loans, they apply now for their first farming loan. Nana T. wants to use her loan to buy adequate quantities of fonio and groundnut seeds, small equipment and farming supplies at the great market in San. After the rainy season, the harvest will be warehoused long enough for its value to increase, before it is sold at the great market in San, in Dah and at the nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. After their produce is sold, the group members expect to make a profit of 26,000 to 27,000 CFA francs each, which they will use to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy farming supplies, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros S. is from the village of Linabu, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 54 years old. Milagros is married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Milagros owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Milagros joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milagros has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Milagros is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Milagros from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia A. is from the village of Canitoan, Lingating, Baungon, Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Letecia is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Letecia owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling used clothing, or ukay-ukay, to the local community members. Letecia has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Letecia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Letecia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 23,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Letecia is requesting a new loan of 26,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Letecia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Bikuweraki Womens Group-Jinja

texts.en:
Fortune finally knocked at her door 6 years ago when she finally took root in her retail franchise that she operates from home. Prior to that, 45-year-old M. Nulu was eking out a relatively low-level living with profits from her modest salon business. The tough experience mill she was brought to terms with whilst still running her salon business was enough to help her dispense with the naiveté of operating a business. The only reliable stock in trade she had to employ in her new business was a strong resolve to succeed and a focused, clear, and sustainable plan of action. These attributes have been her mileage in an invariably competitive retail business field. 

Her shop has an array of goods on display ranging from bags of sugar, bars of soap, and rice. In the course of time, Nulu has come to the realization that never losing sight of one’s objectives principally in operating a business is of paramount importance if one is to achieve short-term and long-term success. 

Though her business doesn’t bring in hefty profits going by the 20,000 shillings she reckons she makes in a week, she is upbeat that her prospects will only get better as long as she can continue biding her time patiently. She is high on conviction that with this loan, she will be able to buy more retail items for her shop. She is looking at buying more bags of sugar, salt, rice and bars of soap, as these are highly demanded items in her locality. She figures she will be able to earn more revenue as a result of the restocking of her shop.

loans.use: The purchase of retail items like bags of sugar,salt and rice

loans.name: Wolale Iv Group

texts.fr:
WOLALE IV  est un regroupement de 10 femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture  de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle constituée de revendeurs  venant généralement des grandes villes.

After their produce is sold, the group members expect to make a profit of 17,000 to 18,500 CFA francs each, which they will use to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy farming supplies, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou F. is from the village of  Blanco , Balingsag Misamis  Oriental. She is 37 years old. Marilou is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting bananas for sale. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marilou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
41-year- old Erlinda D. wants to grow her swine breeding and hog fattening business towards sustainability and profitability.  Hogs she fattened will be sold alive and in volume in the market, while the piglets produced by her swine will be the replacements for the ones sold. Proceeds from this business would enable Erlinda to support the education of her four children, whose ages range from 10 to 16 years old, until they all graduate from college and have earned the degrees they chose. Erlinda believes that this is the best way for them to face their own lives in the future and to have the opportunity to experience it away from the umbrella of poverty. 

Since the income from her hog fattening and swine breeding business can only be earned after four months to one year, Erlinda and her husband have other income to help support their family, especially the educational needs of the children and buying food for the hogs. Her husband earns income as a fish vendor, and Erlinda buys large volumes of herbal medicines, which she sells directly to people in different villages and offices within and outside their own town.

loans.use: To purchase larger volumes of herbal medicines for resale.

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Nhem S., 43, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She weaves Cambodian traditional silk for an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband sells Cambodian traditional cakes, earning an income of USD 2 per day. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase more raw silk to produce more silk products for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more raw silk to produce silk products

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed is 44 years of age and lives with her husband and two children in a city called Borewala in Pakistan. She sews clothes for her neighbors to earn an income. 

Her husband sells clothes. He has a clothes shop in the market. These days her husband is facing the problem of low quantity of stock and is unable to fulfill the requirements of his customers. Therefore, Khursheed is applying for a loan for the second time from Asasah to financially help her husband who will buy stock in bulk for selling. This will not only cut the cost of traveling but also help him to buy the clothes on discount as a result of bulk purchasing. Khursheed is hopeful that these steps will bring happiness to her family and that her family’s living standard will become better.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Mpa-Atabulira Kizinga Group-Jinja

texts.en:
48-year-old K. Robinah has for the last 16 years been able to reliably subsist on the profits from her grocery, salon and commercial motorcycle businesses in Buyala-Jinja. These have been her financial sources of livelihood. With profits from these 3 businesses, Robinah has gone out of her way to see to it that her family’s welfare, especially the educational welfare of her 9 children, is fully catered to. 

Her roots in business can be traced to her erstwhile salon business. As is the story with any person running 2 or 3 businesses, a sense of determination and support from family is essential, she says. She is happily married, and in a week, she makes profits that total 200,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to buy more groceries for her store and some salon equipment.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for her store

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Sen S., 41, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. She is a teacher at a public primary school and earns an income of USD 2.5 per day. She is also a silk weaver when she is available from her school. Her husband is a farmer who grows rice, earning an income of USD 1 per day. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more raw silk to produce more silk products for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more raw silk to produce silk products

loans.name: Wolale V Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE V est composé de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). loans.name: Bakari

texts.en:
Bakari is a married woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and transport.

Bakari has been operating her food stall business for the last year. She sells in a shop and as retail. She has no other source of income.

With the Kshs 35,000 loan, she wants to purchase 50 kg. of sugar, one bundle of maize flour, and wheat flour. Bakari faces the major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. She hopes to operate a wholesale shop in the future and supply to the entire market. She decided to work with Yehu so as to get a loan to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Khaki Womens Association-Jinja Group

texts.en:
32-year-old K. Aisha began her now five-year-old tailoring business with savings from her fish selling business. She operates from her home and her customer base cuts across from community members to schools, interested in well-sewn uniforms. 

In her business, what has helped her find a niche in the market is the top rate quality of most of her designs. With the passage of time, she has seen her profits go up in the ascendant. It’s not only her splendid designs that have been her winning calling card. She is also a high spirited and hard working lady who always creates a pleasant and relaxed atmosphere around her clients. 

Her stable marital status has also in many respects contributed to the stability and growth of her business. Knowing that family is the foundation of society, she has laid special emphasis on the education of her three children. With a profit average of $31 per week, she has been able to make her ends meet. 

Aisha also sells lake shells as an additional source of income. She is now taking a long view with plans of opening up a retail shop and giving her children the best education possible in the future. With this loan she is fully focused on purchasing more clothing textiles and also more shells.

loans.use: Purchasing more clothing textiles and also more lake shells.

loans.name: Kazinga Bakyara Twetungure, Mubende Group

texts.en:
In business, first impressions mean everything. That is one adage that never slips K. Harriet’s mind, who at first operated a retail shop and later gained interest in owning a bar business. In her three years doing a bar business, her commitment, friendly nature and hard work have brought her dividends in Kazinga, Mubende. 

This is the fascinating story of a young divorced mother of three children who is a go-getter in business. Her business since its inception has been steadily bringing her profits to the tune of about $143 on a monthly basis. 

With this loan she is gleefully upbeat that her business will gain further ground, as she intends to buy more stock of drinks like beer, soda and wine. She also sees herself acquiring a motorcycle. This will earn her more revenue and enable her to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: restocking drinks in her pub

loans.name: Wolale Vi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE VI est constitué de 10  femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la  préfecture  de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). In order to ensure that their agricultural investments are profitable, the members of Wolale I Group decided two years ago to participate in the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. After having properly repaid their previous loans, which were solidarity loans, they apply now for their first farming loan. Saran Koni D. wants to use her loan to buy adequate quantities of fonio and groundnut seeds, small equipment and farming supplies at the great market in San. After the rainy season, the harvest will be warehoused long enough for its value to increase, before it is sold at the great market in San and at the nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. After their produce is sold, the group members expect to make a profit of 13,000 to 18,000 CFA francs each, which they will use to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy farming supplies, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Torn

texts.en:
Torn L., 64, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She is a farmer and grows rice for an income of approximately $0.80 per day. Her husband is a three-wheeled cycle driver, earning an income of about $3 per day. 

L. is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike for her child to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  

This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Eoun

texts.en:
Eoun S., 48, is married and resides with her husband and six children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She is a farmer and grows rice for an income of approximately $0.30 per day. 

S.'s husband appears in the photograph. He is a construction worker, earning an income of about $2 per day. Three of the children are employed at a local garment factory and help cover the family expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Wolale Vii Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE VII est constitué de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la  préfecture SAN, (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne 46  ans et au moins 8  enfants. Elles cultivent  de l’arachide, du fonio et du sésame. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents qui étaient des prêts solidaires, elles sont à leur premier prêt de campagne.
ZELE D. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de fonio d’arachide  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles,  au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe WOLALE VII comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de11000 à 13000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Wolale VII Group are married women living in Cinzara, a village in the prefecture of San (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 46 years old and have at least eight children. They grow groundnuts, fonio and sesame. In order to ensure that their agricultural investments are profitable, the members of Wolale I Group decided two years ago to participate in the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. After having properly repaid their previous loans, which were solidarity loans, they apply now for their first farming loan. Zele D. wants to use her loan to buy adequate quantities of fonio and groundnut seeds, small equipment and farming supplies at the great market in San. After the rainy season, the harvest will be warehoused long enough for its value to increase, before it is sold at the great market in San and at the nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. After their produce is sold, the members of Wolale VII Group expect to make a profit of 11,000 to 13,000 CFA francs each, which they will use to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy farming supplies, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: 03.06.10 Dien Bien Group

texts.en:
Thu H. T. (48) is a 48-year-old femaL. living in the town of Thanh Hoa.  Thu is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 03.06.10 Dien Bien.

Thu is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, she provides laundry services to local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND ($158) a month from these activities.

In 2009, Thu joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,248,000 VND.  This previous loan was used to invest in expanding her business.  

She is now requesting a new loan of 5,310,000 VND which again will be used to invest in expanding her business.  This will be her 2nd loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Thu plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  D. T. Lien (49) is a 60-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making and selling food.


2.  D. T. Ha (50) is a 36-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a service-based business.


3.  N. T. G. Thanh (51) is a 41-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.


4.  N. T. Lan (52) is a 74-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


5.  L. T. Hang (155) is a 25-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.


6.  B. T. Tai (53) is a 55-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector operating a fishing business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Thu H. T. (48) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Thu là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 7 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 10- Dien Bien (03.06.10 Dien Bien).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ nói chung cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Thu thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Thu kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2009, Thu đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Thu đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.248.000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.310.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  D. T. Lien (49) là 60 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


2.  D. T. Ha (50) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


3.  N. T. G. Thanh (51) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


4.  N. T. Lan (52) là 74 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.


5.  L. T. Hang (155) là 25 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.248.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.


6.  B. T. Tai (53) là 55 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  D. việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Wolale Viii Group

texts.fr:
WOLALE VIII est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 46  ans, au moins 8  enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide, du fonio et du sésame. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents qui étaient les prêts solidaires, elles sont à leur premier prêt de campagne.
NASOU S. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de fonio d’arachide  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, exclusivement  au grand marché de SAN  ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN, DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 10000 à 12000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Wolale VIII Group are married women living in Cinzara, a village in the prefecture of San in the region of Segou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 46 years old and have at least eight children. They grow groundnuts, fonio and sesame. In order to ensure that their agricultural investments are profitable, the members of Wolale I Group decided two years ago to participate in the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso. After having properly repaid their previous loans, which were solidarity loans, they apply now for their first farming loan. Nasou S. wants to use her loan to buy adequate quantities of fonio and groundnut seeds, small equipment and farming supplies at the great market in San City. After the rainy season, the harvest will be warehoused long enough for its value to increase, before it is sold at the great market in San, in Dah and at the nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. After their produce is sold, the group members expect to make a profit of 10,000 to 12,000 CFA francs each, which they will use to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy farming supplies, seeds and small equipment

loans.name: Wolale Marakaso 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE MARAKASO 1 constitué de 8 femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la  préfecture  de SAN (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mal). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles,  ont en moyenne 37  ans, au moins  5 enfants et  cultivent  exclusivement du sésame.  
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année, d’où leur premier prêt de campagne. 
KADIA S. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence, des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles,  au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte est  stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de SAN, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant à une clientèle composée de revendeurs. 
Elle compte réaliser, après l’écoulement de son produit agricole, un bénéfice de 70.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Wolale Marakaso 1 group is made up of eight married women from the village of Cinzara in the prefecture of San (fourth administrative region of Mali). They live in traditional families, average 27 years of age, have at least five children each and cultivate exclusively sesame. With a view to making their agricultural operations profitable, the group members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program this year, taking out their first farming loan. Kadia S. is planning to use her loan to buy a sufficient quantity of seeds, as well as small machinery and agricultural intrants, at the market in San. After the winter season, her crop is stocked for a certain period of time in order to gain value before it is sold at the large market in San, on a retail basis (but also often wholesale) for cash to a customer base made up of retailers. She expects that once she has sold all her agricultural produce, she will make a profit of 70,000FCFA which will be used for the repayment of interest on the loan and for her family's running costs.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of intrants, seeds and small machinery

loans.name: Y. Gervais

texts.fr: D. D. Y. Gervais est né le 24 Août 1975 à Adjohoun, dans le département de l’Ouémé. Gervais a six enfants à sa charge, dont quatre sont ses propres enfants. Tous ses enfants sont scolarisés. Gervais est un veuf qui vit seul avec ses enfants et assure seul leurs différentes charges. Gervais vit depuis six ans, au quartier Sèkandji, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Gervais n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Pour assurer les différentes charges qui lui reviennent, Gervais a appris la couture, et l’exerce depuis sept ans environs. Parallèlement, Gervais vend des tissus bazins dans son atelier à Sèkandji. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Gervais s’approvisionne. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, Gervais sollicite pour la première fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Gervais ambitionne équiper son atelier de matériels performants et donc moderniser son atelier.
texts.en:
Y. Gervais D. D. was born August 24, 1975 in Adjohoun, in the Ouémé department. Gervais has six children in his care, four of which are his own children. All are in school. Gervais is a widower who lives alone with his children and is the sole breadwinner for the family. For the past six years, Gervais has been living in the neighborhood of Sèkandji, in the commune of Sèmè-Podji. Gervais only attended primary school. To meet his various responsibilities, Gervais learned to sew and has been practicing this activity for about seven years. Gervais also sells bazin fabrics (a type of damask) in his workshop in Sèkandji. He gets his stocks in Dantokpa, Bénin’s international market. In order to strengthen his business and better cope with customer demand, Gervais is seeking his first loan from ALIDÉ. He plans to modernize his workshop by acquiring high-performing equipment.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase bazin fabrics

loans.name: Wolale Marakaso Ii Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE MARAKASO II est constitué de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali, qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles,  ont en moyenne 42 ans,  au moins 4 enfants et  qui cultivent  exclusivement du sésame.  
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année d’où leur premier prêt de campagne.
 AWA K. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles,  au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe  comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 21000 à 23 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Wolale Marakaso II group is composed of married women from the Cinzara village in the San Prefecture (the fourth administrative region of Mal) who live in traditional families, are on the average 42 years old, have four children and cultivate exclusively sesame. In order to make their agricultural work profitable, the group members have decided to join the loan program of Soro Yirwaso and are thus on their first agricultural loan. Awa K. plans to use her loan to purchase an ample quantity of seeds, small tools and agricultural inputs at he big market of San. After the winter season, the harvested produce is stocked for a while as its value goes up, and then sol at the big market in San and at the nearby markets, retail (often wholesale too), for cash, to customers mainly coming from big towns. After selling their produce, the group members plan to obtain a revenue of 21,000 to 23,000 West African Francs each, which will be used to pay off the loan interest as well as ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing agricultural inputs, seeds and small tools

loans.name: Reine Djessougnon

texts.fr: T. Reine Djessougnon est née le 08 Novembre 1990 et vit depuis sa naissance à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Reine est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés et qui vivent avec elle. Reine est séparée de son mari. Ayant arrêté l’école au cours secondaire, Reine a appris ensuite la coiffure. Reine exerce cette activité depuis deux ans, ce qui lui permet de se prendre en charge et d’assurer les diverses charges de ses enfants. Parallèlement, Reine vend dans son atelier des mèches et des produits pour cheveux. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Reine achète ses produits. Dans l’optique d’agrandir son activité et d’accroître sa clientèle par ses produits variés, Reine sollicite pour une première fois, de crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Reine Djessougnon T. was born on November 1990; since birth, she has been living in Ekpè, in the community of Sèmè-Podji. Reine is the mother of two children who attend school and live with her. Reine is separated from her husband. After stopping her studies at the secondary level, she has learned the hairdresser’s trade. She has been in this trade for two years, and it allows her to provide for various needs of her children. In addition, she sells hair extensions and hair care products in her salon. She stocks up in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. With the view of expanding her business and to enlarger her customer based thanks to the diversity of her products, Reine is seeking her first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing hair dryers, hair extensions and hair care products

loans.name: Vasyl'

texts.en:
Vasyl' is married. He lives in Ivano-Frankivsk, Western Ukraine. Vasyl' offers transportation services in the territory of Ukraine. He took a car loan to buy his vehicle and is still repaying it. He has been in business for six years. His current income amounts to approximately $645 a month. 

Besides his transportation business, Vasyl' also works as a heat supply system mechanic in the municipal infrastructure. He was forced to keep his job and balance it with his own business, as it was the only way to provide for his family's needs in a challenging economic environment. 

Vasyl' is seeking a loan of 6,000 UAH to purchase compressed methane gas equipment for his vehicle. He works hard to earn his living and pay his liabilities. Vasyl' has a solid credit history: none of the loans he received was delinquent.

loans.use: to purchase compressed gas equipment for his vehicle

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a widow. Her husband passed away a few months ago and left her with two children, both of whom attend school. She also takes care of additional family members. 

She plans to use this loan to buy more jerycans of local brew (gin). Rose changed her business from owning a food stall in Naguru to selling local gin a few months ago and she has no additional income. She operates her business from home and so doesn’t pay rent. 

She buys jerycans of local brew once a week from Nakulabye market and uses public transport to and from Nakulabye.  Her customers are the local people around the area. She works seven days a week and depends on this job for a living. Her business challenges are seasonality and transportation.   

Rose decided to work with MCDT because it was offering loans at low interest.  She owns and resides in a two-room house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include food, medication and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more jerycans of local gin

loans.name: Wolale Marakaso Iii Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe WOLALE MARAKASO III est constitué de femmes mariées du village de CINZARA dans la préfecture de SAN région (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans, au moins 6  enfants et  cultivent  exclusivement du sésame.  
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année d’où leur premier prêt de campagne. 
S. DIARRA compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles,  au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 13500 à 14500 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
The Wolale Marakaso III group is made up of women from the village of Cinzana in the San district in the fourth administrative region of Mali. They are all married and live in traditional extended families. They have an average age of 39 and each has at least 6 children. They all exclusively grow sesame.
In the hope of making their agricultural efforts more profitable, the group members decided to participate in Soro Yiriwaso’s credit program on their first farming loan.
S. Diarra intends to use her loan to buy seeds, some small supplies and fertilizers at the big market in San. Once winter is over, she stores her harvested crops for a while to gain market value before selling them at the big market in San and the surrounding markets. She sells retail (often wholesale) for cash, to customers mostly from bigger cities.
After selling their produce, each group member hopes to make a profit of 13,500 to 14,500 XOF to go towards paying the loan’s interest and everyday family expenses.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizers, seeds and other small materials

loans.name: K. Geneviève

texts.fr: Née le 16 Mai 1981 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, NOUTAÏ K. Geneviève est mariée à ADEGUELOU Victorin, un enseignant. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a sept ans que Geneviève s’est installée à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, où elle vit avec sa famille. Le couple se partage ensemble les diverses charges familiales. Geneviève n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire, mais a appris ensuite la coiffure. Geneviève exerce cette activité depuis deux ans. A côté de cette activité, Geneviève vend des mèches et des produits pour cheveux, ce qui lui permet d’avoir plusieurs sources de revenus. Face à la demande considérable de sa clientèle, Geneviève désire augmenter le stock de ses produits et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Geneviève sollicite pour une première fois un prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born on May 16, 1981 in Cotonou, the econimc capital of Bénin, K. Geneviève NOUTAÏ is married to Victorin ADEGUELOU, a teacher. The couple has two children both of whom are in school. Seven years ago Geneviève moved to Ekpè, in the Sèmè-Podji commune, where she lives with her family. The couple shares the various familial responsibilities. Geneviève only attended primary school, but then learned how to be a hairdresser. She has been operating this business for two years. As a side business, Geneviève sells hair pieces and hair products, which provides her with several sources of income. Given the considerable customer demand, Geneviève would like to increase her stock of products and be able to better satisfy her customers. This is why she is requesting a first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hair pieces and hair products

loans.name: Mahouton Bruno

texts.fr: K. Mahouton Bruno est né en 1972 à Djèrègbé, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Bruno vit depuis une vingtaine d’année à Djèrègbé et est marié à DOSSOU Solange, une coiffeuse. Le couple a quatre enfants, et deux autres enfants à leur charge. Seulement certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Bruno vit à Djèrègbé avec sa femme et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Bruno a très peu fréquenté l’école, et a appris la mécanique auto. Depui cinq ans, Bruno exerce cette activité. De façon secondaire, Bruno vend des pièces détachées (pièces de rechange) à Djèrègbé. Bruno s’approvisionne au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin. C’est la première fois que Bruno sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un prêt, afin d’élargir son champ d’activité et d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire. Plus tard, Bruno ambitionne ouvrir une boutique pour y vendre ses articles.
texts.en:
Mahouton Bruno K. was born in 1971 in Djèrègbé, in the commune of Sèmè-Podji, Benin. For the past twenty years or so Bruno has lived in Djèrègbé, and he is married to Solange Dossou, who is a hairstylist. The couple have four children as well as two others who are in their care. Only some of the children have received schooling. Bruno lives in Djèrègbé with his wife and children. Together, the couple take care of the family's various expenses. Bruno did not spend much time in school, and he learned auto mechanics, a profession that he has been carrying out for the last five years. As a secondary occupation he sells spare parts in Djèrègbé. He gets his supplies in Nigeria, a neighboring state to Benin. This is the first time that Bruno has has asked for a loan from ALIDé in order to widen his field of activity and increase his turnover. Later, Bruno hopes to open a store where he can sell his items.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Gbadechiré Emilienne

texts.fr: K. Gbadechiré Emilienne est née le 19 Septembre 1979 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à DADA Jean, un soudeur, Emilienne est mère de deux enfants, dont un est scolarisé. Seulement un enfant est à sa charge. Depuis environs sept ans, Emilienne réside à Ekpè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, avec sa famille. Le couple se partage les diverses charges familiales. Emilienne n’a pas fréquenté l’école, mais a appris la coiffure. Emilienne exerce cette activité depuis onze ans et vend également des mèches et des produits pour cheveux dans son atelier. Emilienne désire augmenter le stock de ses produits et équiper son salon de coiffure, de produits divers et variés afin d’attirer plus la clientèle. Eu égard à cela, Emilienne sollicite pour la première fois un prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Gbadechiré Emilienne was born on 19 September 1979 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Jean Dada, a welder, Emilienne is the mother of two children, of whom one has received schooling. Only one child is in her care. For about seven years, Emilienne has lived in Ekpè, in the commune of Sèmè-Podji, with her family. The couple share the various family expenses. Emilienne did not go to school but learned hairstyling. She has been carrying out this profession for eleven years and also sells hair extensions and hair care products in her workshop. Emilienne wishes to increase her stock of products and equip her hair salon with different and varied products so as to attract more customers. For this reason, Emilienne is asking for a loan from ALIDé for the first time.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase hair extensions and hair styling products.

loans.name: Omunaku Kaghama Jinja Womens Group

texts.en:
If one is to cast their mind back to the Ugandan days of old, they will be brought to terms with the fact that most people earned their livelihood through subsistence farming.  61-year-old N. Rose is old enough to call to mind those days. Sixteen years ago she was more inclined to subsistence farming until she realized the old status quo had changed, as many farmers today are commercially oriented, planting cash crops that bring them return value profits at the end of every harvest season. 

She decided then that she had to start a tailoring business where she mostly sold the clothes she had sewn in Buwenda-Jinja. Being a widow, she knew she had her responsibility cut out for her. With six children to take care of, she knew only hard work would be her saving grace. And her saving grace it truly has been, as she is seeing the dividends. In a week, profits from her business average up to $27. She also has a poultry business. With this loan, she wants to buy an electric sewing machine that will make her work much faster and more improved.

loans.use: To purchase of an electric sewing machine

loans.name: Tina

texts.en:
Tina is divorced. She has two grown children: a son Leonid and a daughter Victoria. She is an entrepreneur from Novomoskovsk. Tina sells menswear in the central marketplace of her home town. She always tries to keep up with fashion trends and re-stocks her inventory on a regular basis. Tina has been in the trade for ten years. Presently, she has nearly $3200 in inventory. Her monthly net profit amounts to about $826. 

Tina is requesting a loan of 12,000 UAH to purchase school uniforms for boys for the upcoming fall season when school begins. Her son is actively helping her run the clothing venture. Tina is hoping to continue expanding her business and provide for her family. Tina can be characterized as a loyal and consistent partner and reliable borrower.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 49-year-old woman from Lebanon. After the death of her husband, she found herself alone and responsible for two children. So she decided to take charge of the operation of her husband's mini-market. She has been working hard to pay her family's expenses. She offers all types of products: food products, cereals, soft drinks, detergents, etc. The mini-market has been established for almost sixteen years and it is known by a good number of clients. She is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase her store’s inventory. She hopes that the variety of products presented to her clients will continue to earn profit for her family.

It is very common in Lebanon to find small supermarkets, selling both perishable and non-perishable goods. As members of the communities themselves, store owners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demands. The strong network of community relationships are an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in smaller towns and villages.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese micro-finance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in micro-finance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: increase her store’s inventory

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila is married with a grown son. She lives in Novomoskovsk and runs a construction supply store called "Construction Fittings" that is located in the central marketplace. She doesn't own the facility but has to rent it which increases her business expenses. Her rented facility is spacious enough and is located in a busy part of the marketplace which always keeps her place buzzing with customers. She has been working in this sphere of business for three years. 

Ludmila is seeking a loan of 15,000 Grivnyas to purchase more construction fittings, metalware, tools and instruments to diversify the assorted merchandise she offers for sale in her store. This loan will help her obtain a better variety of inventory for the busy summer/fall reconstruction and remodeling season in the Ukraine.

Ludmila's husband is actively helping her run the business. Ludmila is an optimist. She thanks God for opportunities He opened for her business and for the success she has achieved with it.

loans.use: To purchase more construction fittings, metalware, tools and instruments for her store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is an entrepreneur from Kamenka. She lives in this predominantly agricultural region of Ukraine and sells seeds, fertilizers and polyethylene film to local farmers who run small farms with greenhouses. Olga and her husband started their small business ten years ago. Since then they have already invested about 170,000 Grivnyas in the venture and have three vending locations.

Olga is planning to use this loan of 18,000 Grivnyas to purchase additional rolls of polyethylene film and more seeds for sale in the farming market. One of her long-term plans is to continue expanding and to add agricultural machinery to their inventory, e.g. mini-tractors and other equipment.

loans.use: To purchase more seeds and polyethylene film wholesale

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is married and has a 12-year-old daughter. Natalya sells children's clothing in the central market in Novomoskovsk, owning several vending kiosks in the same marketplace. She launched her start-up four years ago and presently has over 65,000 Grivnyas invested in the business. Her income amounts to 20,000 Grivnyas a month.

Natalya is requesting a loan of 11,000 Grivnyas to purchase additional merchandise for the upcoming fall season. In Ukraine, the school year begins in September and students are required to wear uniforms. Natalya wants to buy them in bulk for retail sale in August.

Natalya is an experienced vendor. She knows what a customer wants and tries to meet the demand. She is hoping to generate additional income and finish remodeling her new apartment which she bought only a year ago.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise for the upcoming fall season

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 22-year-old young woman from Lebanon who lives with her family and four siblings. She works in producing handicrafts and artisanal souvenirs and producing accessories. Despite her young age, she has been working for several years in this type of job and her handmade products are very much requested by her clients. She works on a freelance basis upon request of her clients and offers a diversity of models in a catalogue to give her customers the opportunity to choose from a variety of designs. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to further diversify her merchandise selection and to be able to make more products. She hopes that, with the help of the loan, her sales will increase and therefore her income. She wishes that, one day, she will open her own handmade accessories store and that she will have a big commercial name in this market. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (e.g. blanking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese micro-finance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in micro-finance. At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement to its micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US$115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please click here.

loans.use: To diversify her merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 20-year-old single man living with his family and four siblings in Lebanon. This young man has been working in a tattoo parlor for the past three years. He makes all kind of designs, and he is very talented on his occupation. He said that he chose this occupation because he feels that it is an art, and he’s very thankful for his decision.
